channel.title: Psychedelic Salon
channel.description: Your source for cutting edge information about the exploration and expansion of consciousness. Featured speakers include Terence McKenna, Alex Grey, Daniel Pinchbeck, Erik Davis, Ann and Sasha Shulgin, Nick Sand, Timothy Leary, Robert Anton Wilson and more. You can access all of these podcasts for free at PsychedelicSalon.org or through MatrixMasters.net/salon/

item.title: 390-TMcKenna: "Monogamy, Marriage, and Neurosis"
item.description: In today's podcast, Terence McKenna describes his Utopian ideal of a world with only one man for every three women. A few interesting quotes include: “This nuclear family thing is, I think, part of the root of our problem, that it is an engine for the production of neurotic, dysfunctional people.” . . . and “If guys really got as much sex as they think they want they would probably hand over the machinery of civilization without a fight.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 389-TMcKenna: "Gathering Momentum for a Leap"
item.description: Today's podcast continues with the February 1994 Terence McKenna workshop in which he says, among other things: “The 20th century is a great gathering for a leap, and the 19th century was the century of the gentleman.” and “Whether we can actually make a new world is not clear because the momentum of the past is very great.”

item.title: 388- Greer: "Wherever You Are, Be There!"
item.description: Today we return to the 2013 Palenque Norte Lectures at the Burning Man Festival. Our featured speaker is Dr. George Greer, M.D. who among other things is a co-founder, medical director, and secretary of the Heffter Research Institute, which has been at the forefront of psychedelic research since 1993. In this talk, Dr. Greer explains some mental exercises that have the potential to move your consciousness up a level or so and 'on the natch'. As one of the early researchers into MDMA (Ecstasy), George has some professional insights about the drug, such as: “My thought about MDMA is that it blocks the fear response to a perceived emotional threat.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 387-TMcKenna: "February 1994 Workshop Introduction"
item.description: One term that he uses in this talk is something that must have been used frequently before, however, I don't remember hearing about “the DEFINING dose” before. Additionally, Terence gives a beautifully word-sculpted description of the increasingly complex layers involved in visual hallucinations. Another interesting comment he made was that he would be signing into the Internet for his first time. Also his somewhat negative view of the Net at that time is quite interesting in light of his highly positive view of the Net just a few years later. Finally, near the end of this talk he tells us what he thinks about reincarnation.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 386-TMcKenna: "Loose Ends Time"
item.description: Today we join Terence McKenna for the final session of a weekend workshop that was held in May of 1990. Here he lets the workshop attendees direct the conversation by asking question, among which are: 1. What does archaic revival mean? 2. Do you think one day psychedelics will be legal and encouraged? 3. Will you talk more about seeing language? 4. Why do you focus so much on visual hallucinations? 5. Who or what do you think these psychedelic entities are? And 6. How do you invoke a conversation with the mushroom? One of my favorite McKenna quotes from this conversation is, “You talk about a well-kept secret that's only two tokes away? How do they keep the lid on this? That's the miracle to me. How do they keep the lid on this?” [smoked NN-DMT]
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 385-Griffiths: "Current Psychedelic Research"
item.description: “Psilocybin is a pharmacological tool that helps people recognize how it feels to embody the present moment. And that's exactly the same of meditation. It's about bringing yourself into the present moment.” -Roland Griffiths In this wide-ranging report on the current state of psychedelic research being conducted at Johns Hopkins Medicine, Dr. Roland Griffiths talks about the work that is being done by a team of researchers who are investigating psychedelic medicines and psychedelic states of consciousness. Dr. Griffiths speaks about their research into the character of one's personality in regards to how a psychedelic experience may affect a person's openness to the experiences of life. Another interesting area that his research group is investigating is the intersection of psilocybin and meditation, a discussion of which takes up a significant part of this talk.

item.title: 384-Oak: "Sex, Aging, and Psychedelics"
item.description: Today we feature a Palenque Norte Lecture given by Annie Oak at the 2013 Burning Man Festival. This groundbreaking founder of the Woman's Visionary Congress continues to push the envelope of psychedelic discussion into two of the most important issues of all to humans, sexuality and aging. Additionally, Annie issues several challenges to us all as we continue to expand our own consciousnesses.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 383-TMcKenna: "A Psychedelic Point of View"
item.description: In a somewhat meandering discourse, Terence reveals (among other things) his thoughts about the possibilities of an afterlife, particularly in light of what he knows about shamanism. He then goes on to give an interesting critique of monotheism, saying, among other things, “It's the monotheistic religions that have to take a real knock for the present situation.” His comments on language and culture include: “Language is something unfinished in us. It is something that was catalyzed out of animal organization by hallucinogenic activation of brain states, and it is something that is in the act of perfecting itself.” . . . “When you go into a culture, you're going to make a choice. And all cultures represent narrowing of choices.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 382-TMcKenna: "The Psychedelic Option"
item.description: Once again we join Terence McKenna for a romp through his fascinating mind. While the main thrust of his comments deal with the imagination and the concept of spirituality, he also chases a few eternal questions such as, “What do you think is going on? What do you think this is all about? Who do you think you are? What do you think English is? How do you really cognize notions like the future, the past, where I've been, what I want?” Unfortunately, he doesn't directly answer these questions but rather provides us with a few more analytical tools to help us answer these questions on our own. My favorite quote from this talk is, “And, in fact, the evidence is building that our style of society is the historical equivalent of a temper tantrum.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 381-TMcKenna: "A Stiff Dose of Psychedelics"
item.description: This podcast begins a series of talks from a Terence McKenna workshop that was held in May of 1990. In this presentation we hear Terence's introductory remarks at the opening session. Topics touched upon include “Archaic Virtual Reality” and “How Do We Say It Right?”. Two of my favorite quotes from this lecture are: “Outlandish things are going on inside the psychedelic experience. It seems to imply the thing we had hardly dared hope, which is that the world is whatever you say it is if you know how to say it right.” and “Science fiction I really consider a proto-psychedelic drug, because what science fiction does is it gives permission to imagine.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 380-Lorenzo: "Confessions of an Ecstasy Advocate"
item.description: This relatively short podcast features the audio portion of a film by Tom Huckabee and George Wada in conjunction with “The Starck Project”, a documentary soon to be released. The short film consists primarily of an interview with Lorenzo Hagerty dealing with the introduction of MDMA (Ecstasy) to the street scene in Dallas, Texas during the 1980s.

item.title: 379-Starfox: "Divine Androgyny"
item.description: This podcast features Jae Starfox's 2013 Palenque Norte Lecture, which was delivered at the Burning Man Festival. In their talk, Jae provides a candid look into some of the issues that transgender people are faced with as they make their way through a sometimes less than friendly world. As more and more people are beginning to deal with their own gender related issues, this talk provides some little discussed but very important information. Following Jae's talk I play a short segment from my interview on the Joe Rogan podcast in which we also discuss gender issues.

item.title: 378-TMcKenna: "A Psychedelic Point of View"
item.description: Today we are going to be hearing the final session of a month long workshop that Terence McKenna led in June of 1989. While he again covers a wide range of topics, this is one of his more impassioned talks, and it remains right on point in today's world. One of his more interesting raps is his take on what he calls the priesthood of science and promotes instead a psychedelic point of view, which he defines as: “A psychedelic point of view means a point of view which honors consciousness.” And for those of us who are constantly trying to better understand the cosmos he has these words of wisdom: “You do not measure the depth of a universal mystery with the neural network of a primate. . . . Our role is not to understand but to appreciate.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 377-TMcKenna: "An Ecology of Souls"
item.description: Today we pick up with the next to last installment of a workshop given by Terence McKenna in the Summer of 1989. In addition to the title that I've given this talk, topics include: “Reason, Intuition, & Evolution”, “There is a Telos of Some Sort”, “Alchemy and Evolution”, “Designing Our Future”, “Evolution and Revolution”, “The Month of Remember”, “Flux is the Only Standard”, “Changing Our Archetypes”, “The Last Illusion”, “An Ecology of Souls”. Among many interesting quotes from this talk is this one: “Do we know what we behold? We need to know what we behold because inevitably we become what we behold.”

item.title: 376-Jabbor: "Coming Out of the Psychedelic Closet"
item.category: Culture, War on Drugs, Psychedelics, Student Activists
item.description: For anyone under the age of 30, this may be the most important podcast in the salon. Daniel Jabbor is a young entrepreneur and drug policy activist who, among many other accomplishments, and in a very short period of time, founded the now 4,000+ strong Psychedelic Society of San Francisco. Today's podcast features two of Daniel's talks, one from the recent Palenque Norte Lecture Series at the 2013 Burning Man Festival, and another from a psychedelic conference at which he detailed some of the successes of the SSDP, Students for a Sensible Drug Policy. No matter what your age, this is an important message for you to think about. If you know history, you know that quite often it is the young people who are the ones to change its course. These talks by Daniel Jabbor will give you more positive hope for the future than you have had in a long time.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 375-Adams: "Story Time with Ken Adams"
item.description: Today we get to hear another of the Palenque Norte Lectures that were held at the 2013 Burning Man Festival. This talk features the artist, experimental film maker, micro-publisher, and media developer, Ken Adams, who for many years was a close friend and neighbor of the late Terence McKenna. You will be delighted with some of the true stories Ken tells as we get to wander with him through the mind of a uniquely creative artist. Also, I tell a couple of my 'grandfather stories', and we finish with Ron Shock telling the greatest dope story ever.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 374-TMcKenna: "Bootstrapping Ourselves"
item.description: In today's lecture, which was given in the summer of 1989, Terence McKenna begins by talking about some of the things that he finds strange about numbers. From there he goes on to tell a few new and funny stories from his adventure at La Chorera. He then goes on to challenge the psychedelic community to take a closer look at itself in regards to if (and if not why not) we have used these medicines to actually become better people. The question he poses is: “Do we embody the radiant correctness of what we say we are pursuing.” He also tells us how he now views the “Sixties”.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 373-TMcKenna: "Thoughts About Gnosticism, Art, and Music"
item.description: Continuing with our Terence McKenna workshop we join him in discussion various topics that are raised by the attendees. In one rap he talks about the repugnance of being a slave to an ideology and says, “And that what we really want, in the domain of planning, is an abandonment of ideology, that ideology is poisonous, all ideology is poisonous.” and then goes on to the importance of being a heretic and says, “You just can't go wrong as a heretic, because they're always vindicated.” and “Permission for heresy is never a bad idea.” Among other topics, Terence also tells us what he originally dreamed of as a career when he was young, along with some of his thoughts about music.

item.title: 372-TMcKenna: "The Intentionality of Meaning"
item.category: Language, Psychedelics, Culture, Politics, War on Drugs
item.description: Today we again join Terence McKenna in a 1989 workshop where he explores language in the context of the War on Drugs. Some of my favorite quotes from this talk include: “The world is not made of anti-mu mesons, quarks, and photons, and electromagnetic fields. Reality is made of words.” . . . “Culture is more and more consciously becoming a project carried out in the domain of language by, for instance, propaganda both governmental and commercial.” . . . and “Television, introduced at the close of World War II, has become a form of electronic heroin, and it isn't even your trip. They don't even let you go on your own trip, you get a trip designed by Madison Avenue.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.itunes:summary: Today we again join Terence McKenna in a 1989 workshop where he explores language in the context of the War on Drugs. Some of my favorite quotes from this talk include: “The world is not made of anti-mu mesons, quarks, and photons, and electromagnetic fields. Reality is made of words.” . . . “Culture is more and more consciously becoming a project carried out in the domain of language by, for instance, propaganda both governmental and commercial.” . . . and “Television, introduced at the close of World War II, has become a form of electronic heroin, and it isn't even your trip. They don't even let you go on your own trip, you get a trip designed by Madison Avenue.”

item.title: 371-Gilmore: "Civil Rights In Cyberspace"
item.category: Internet, Privacy, NSA, Spying, War on Drugs, Cannabis, Marijuana, EFF
item.description: Today we feature the first of the 2013 Palenque Norte Lectures that were held at the recent Burning Man Festival, and our guest speaker is John Gilmore, who among many other accomplishments is a co-founder of the Electric Frontier Foundation (EFF). John is also a board member of the Marijuana Policy Project and of MAPS. In his talk he touches on the future of drug legalization in the U.S. as well as several topics concerning the work of EFF in light of the recent revelations about the U.S. Government's systematic program of spying on all of its citizens in ways that would put the now defunct Soviet Union to shame.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 370-TMcKenna: "Modeling Human History"
item.description: Today Terence McKenna picks up his inquiry into the concept of time from the standpoint of human history. He points out that, in the overall history of the planet, the sum total of human history is, in the amount of time it has covered, like a lightening strike. Also, he gives a more complete explanation of the workings of the I Ching. My favorite quote from this talk, which I'm not sure I completely understand, is: “We are like coral animals in a vast reef of excreted technological material that is wired for solid state data transfer.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 369-TMcKenna: "Timothy & Terence"
item.description: Today's podcast features that legendary night in June of 1991 where, in Los Angeles, Dr. Timothy Leary introduced Terence McKenna, who delivered the evening's lecture. His topics included a plea for the preservation of the Rainforest and alchemy, among other things. Here are a couple of my favorite quotes from this talk: “What 'psychedelic' means is getting your mind out in front of you, by whatever means necessary, so that you can relate to it as a thing in the world and then work upon it.” And one of my all-time favorites, “You've been told from the cradle that the deck was stacked against you, fall of man, original sin, and so forth and so on. It's bullshit. It's absolute bullshit.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 368-TMcKenna: "Psychedelics and the Feminine"
item.category: Culture, Psychedelics, DMT, Feminine, Gaia, Aliens
item.description: In this installment of a June 1989 workshop, Terence McKenna adds a few new twists to some of his often-told tales, for example, by comparing a DMT trip to an automobile accident. Also, for the first time that I remember hearing it, he gives a very interesting opinion about where you GO when you smoke DMT. And I'm not talking about where to go in this physical universe, but about 'WHERE' the place is, and WHAT the place is that you seem to be in while you are in the thrall of the experience. He concludes by comparing our current human situation to that of the apes in the movie 2001 who were dancing around the monolith. In our case the monolith is psychedelic substances. All we know right now, he says, is that we've discovered something that may be as important to us as fire.

item.title: 367-TMcKenna: "The Evolution of a Psychedelic Thinker"
item.description: Terence begins by telling us that even as a child he was what we now call psychedelic, and it was then that he decided he would “entertain any idea but believe in nothing”. From there we are treated with a romp through the evolving mind of Terence McKenna, who, as usual, touches on a wide variety of topics in the introduction to a workshop that was held in June of 1989. Some of his thought-provoking comments include: “Nothing is as boundary dissolving, except for psychedelic compounds, as travel. Travel is up there.” . . . “Without an understanding and a familiarity of the psychedelic experience you should be sued for fraud if you're practicing psychotherapy.” . . . “What the psychedelics are for us as a species, rather than for each one of us as an individual, what they are for us as a species is an enzyme that catalyzes the language-making capacity.” . . . And famously: “I have nothing but scorn for all weird ideas other than my own.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 366-TMcKenna: "Suggested Reading List"
item.description: This is the final segment of a workshop that Terence McKenna led over the Easter Weekend in 1988. It begins with Terence giving his recommended psychedelic reading list of more than a dozen books. (Links to them may be found in today's program notes.) He then moves on to a discussion of what he calls “one of the most mysterious passages in the New Testament. This leads to his story of the experiment in La Chorrera but in a way that I don't remember hearing before. Quite descriptive of interesting mind-states. One of my favorite quotes from this talk is, “We are at such a primitive stage of culture that we haven't yet understood what time is.”

item.title: 365-TMcKenna: "Effects of Psychedelics on Society"
item.description: Today's podcast features the next installment of a 1988 workshop that was let by Terence McKenna. Among other interesting topics he covers here is his take on the drug culture of the 1960s and how the lack of a shamanism model for LSD caused some unforeseen consequences and why what he calls “the first psychedelic revolution” got into trouble. A couple of my favorite sound bites from this conversation include: “And science, when it examines psychedelics, as it will and must, is going to discover a revolution, I believe, that will put all the previous revolutions in perspective.” And, speaking about science, “Nobody should be allowed more than fifty years to get their act together.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 364-TMcKenna: "Communicating with the Mushroom"
item.description: Today we begin the Q&A session from another Terence McKenna workshop. As usual, the topics covered were quite wide-ranging. Here are a few of my favorite quotes: “What you call man is time.” [Quoting the mushroom.] . . . “What happens with DMT is you leap over all the barriers in the first few seconds. Unlike mushrooms where over hours and hours on a high dose you might navigate yourself to the center of the Mandela, DMT is like being struck by metaphysical lightening.” . . . “History is the siren song of the soul.”

item.title: 363-Stolaroff: "A Venice Beach Salon"
item.description: In the spring of 2006, at Kathleen's Salon in Venice Beach, California, Robert Forte and Myron Stolaroff came to tell their stories about the recent festivities in Basil, Switzerland that celebrated the 100th anniversary of the birth of Dr. Albert Hofmann, the discoverer of LSD. After telling a little about the Hofmann event, Myron read part of the talk that he gave in Basil. From there, the conversation ranged widely eventually ending with an argument about the Kennedy assassination.

item.title: 362-Leary: "Flashbacks"
item.description: Today's podcast features Dr. Timothy Leary reading a few selected chapters from his autobiography, Flashbacks. Interestingly, he begins this recording with Chapter 19, which details with his departure from Harvard. The last chapter that he included on this tape ends with his escape, barely, from prison. Of course, since we now know the rest of the story, the relief he obviously felt after escaping was very short lived. One of his more amusing quotes from this reading is when he called Harvard University a “finishing school for Fortune 500 executives”.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 361-Lorenzo: "Catlin's Salon"
item.description: Today's podcasts is from the audio book edition of my novel, The Genesis Generation. It consists of a reading of Chapter 9, Catlin's Salon. This is a fictional account of what was once the most fashionable psychedelic salon on the West Coast. Once each month, for more than eight years, an amazing group of people would gather to discuss a mind-numbing array of topics. And while the story line in my novel is obviously fictional, the backdrop of the salon itself is described as best I can . . . and as best that I now remember, looking back after so many years that have passed since those wondrous meetings of the L.A. Chapter of the Albert Hofmann Society.

item.title: 360-Shonagh: "Medicine Oracle & Spellbreaker"
item.description: Today we feature a talk given by Shonagh Home at the East West Bookstore in Seattle, Washington early in 2013. Shonagh is an author, shaman and spell breaker, who takes her students beyond the cultural mass-trance and into the territory of the sacred. In the Pacific Northwest she teaches workshops that are deeply transformative, helping people to release from old behavior patterns and access a wealth of inner resources. She says about herself, “I think of myself as a spiritual warrior, and a spiritual warrior seeks to know, they are on a quest to know.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 359-TMcKenna: "The Real Message of Psychedelics"
item.description: While once again the discussion varied widely from topic to topic, one of the most interesting parts of this recording is where Terence reveals his thoughts about how to teach children about psychedelic medicines. His bottom line on this is to be truthful and avoid hypocrisy. Perhaps the most interesting comment he makes though is when he says what he intends to do on December 22, 2012 if nothing happens. Also there is a fascinating discussion about how and when to tell your children that you are psychedelic.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 358-TMcKenna: "This Psychedelic Thing"
item.description: We continue today with a workshop led by Terence McKenna in August of 1993. Since the topics covered depended upon the questions that the participants asked, a wide range of subjects is again covered. One interesting side story he touches on is that while he often described parts of DMT visions as containing jeweled Faberge eggs, he admits that he could also have described them in other ways as well. Also, he gives his opinion about both the New Age and so-called modern science. One of my favorite quotes from this talk is: “One of the motivations for my career is to get other people to check [DMT] out, because here is truly confounding data that you don't have to make an expedition to the heart of the Amazon, or battle your way through hours of waves of nausea and dark spaces, chanting your mantra obsessively. I mean, when you smoke DMT, 30 seconds later you're in the presence of the unspeakable, and the show is going full blast.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 357-TMcKenna: "Fungi Questions"
item.description: He gets off to a quick start by speculating about what would happen if we could all create an accurate virtual reality simulation of our psychedelic experiences and then share them with one another. Once he gets really warmed up he takes off on a critique of Christianity that you won't want to miss. Next he expands on the idea that only Islam provides what some people consider to be 'traditional' values. And then, of course, there is the mushroom: “The fungi became, or is for some mysterious reason still to be discovered, a pipeline into a mind, an entelechy, which we can only image as feminine and can only associate somehow to the environment, to the ecosystem. This is the Gaian mind. This is what the goddess really is. The goddess is a network of connective intelligence that is operating on this planet.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 356-TMcKenna: "The Psychedelic 'Religious' Agenda"
item.description: In today’s podcast we get to hear Terence McKenna questioning himself about his emerging role in our culture, even calling himself “perhaps a dancing bear”. He then goes on to describe, with some incredulity, his performances on stage at various raves. The talk itself is from the opening night of a weekend workshop in during the month of August 1993. A few of my favorite quotes from this talk include: “Not reckless dose but committed dose. Not to see if it works. It works, other people have established that. You don't need to do research to confirm that it's psychoactive.” . . . “The truth, for sure, when it arrives, will make you smile. If it doesn't you should seek a deeper truth.” . . . “The real test of your psychedelic authenticity is your ability to write a novel.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 355-Various: "Building a Psychedelic Community"
item.description: Today's podcast features a panel discussion with Annie Oak, Twilight, and Bruce Damer that took place at the 2012 Palenque Norte Lectures held at that year's Burning Man Festival. While this is not a “how to” discussion with specific steps, it is larger in scope in that the panelists and audience exchange thoughts about some of the more important components of a high functioning psychedelic community. At the end of the podcast, Lorenzo explains why he will no longer respond to email coming from accounts that have been spied upon by the government. He then talks about additional security measures our community should be thinking of to protect our personal data from government spies.

item.title: 354-Garfield: "Pre-End of the World Special"
item.description: Today we only go back in time a short way, back to December 12, 2012 when Matt Pallmary and Michael Garfield took a break during their work on the stage production of Matt's novel, “Land Without Evil”, in Austin, Texas. In this wide ranging discussion between salon favorite, Matt Pallamary, and long time saloner, burner, artist, and musician, Michael Garfield, one of my favorite topics was Michael's very positive take on the long-term impact of the work of Terence McKenna, regardless of the fact that the Timewave theory had obviously been disproven. Michael is also a regular performer on the festival circuit, and his schedule may be found online at www.michaelgarfield.net.

item.title: 353-TMcKenna: "Inflationary Evolution"
item.description: Today's podcast features the closing session of a workshop that Terence McKenna led in December of 1994. Here is a little sample of some of the topics he covered that Sunday morning: “Chaos is roving through the system and able to undo, at any point, the best laid plans.” . . . “Because the planetary culture is becoming ever more closely knitted together all its parts are becoming co-dependent.” . . . “National governments are under paid, under staffed, and under talented.” . . . “Don't worry. You don't know enough to worry. . . . Who do you think you are that you should worry, for cryin' out loud. It's a total waste of time. It presupposes such a knowledge of the situation that it is, in fact, a form of hubris.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 352-TMcKenna: "The Amazing Thing About Psychedelics"
item.description: We continue again with a workshop given by Terence McKenna in December of 1994. Some of his interesting comments about psychedelics include: “You see, the amazing thing about psychedelics is it doesn't depend on a state of grace. It doesn't depend on allegiance to a leader. It doesn't even depend on a special diet or theological predilection The astonishing news about these psychedelic experiences is: You don't have to go to India for ten years. You don't have to be chosen by Baba-G. This works for most people, and would probably work for you.” And, “If you think that you've got it all figured out, and you haven't ever had an intense, boundary-dissolving psychedelic, then you're absolutely out to lunch. You don't know what's going on. It's like the opinions of eleven year old boys about sexuality.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 351-TMcKenna: "What Is Truth?"
item.description: Today we pick up once again on a workshop that Terence McKenna gave at the end of 1994. Like many of his events, his remarks were driven by questions from those in attendance. One of the most interesting of his riffs is in answer to a question about what the differences were between experiences driven by ayahuasca, by psilocybin, by DMT, and by LSD. Two of my favorite quotes from this talk are: “If you go to Paris you know more about reality than people who don't. If you smoke DMT you know more about reality than people who don't.” And, “In the Newtonian and print-created social space that we're walking around in you are like a self-extracting archive that hasn't self-extracted itself yet. And then you take psilocybin and you self-extract and unfold.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 350-Souther: "Healing Through Sound and Ayahuasca"
item.description: Today's talk by Hamilton Souther is, in my opinion, the most enlightening presentation about ayahuasca that we have yet heard here in the salon. If you are here for the first time, and are looking for information about ayahuasca, this is a great place to begin. In addition to one of the best descriptions of what takes place in one's mind during an ayahuasca ceremony, Hamilton also provides some excellent advice about journeying in the Amazon: “[When interviewing a shaman] especially look at everybody in the eyes. The eyes in ayahuasca tell you everything. If you see people with eyes that get really glossed over and become really shifty, it's letting you know something there is going on that maybe you don't want to become like that. Maybe that's not why you're there.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 349-TMcKenna: "A Higher Dimensional Sectioning of Reality"
item.description: Today we return to the December 1994 workshop given by Terence McKenna. As usual, he covered a wide range of topics. Here is a sampling of his thoughts that morning: “Just because you have a nut theory it doesn't mean that you agree with other nut theories. In fact, it often makes you very hostile to them. After all, there's a limited pool there that we're all after.” . . . “Because I believe psychedelics are a kind of higher dimensional sectioning of reality, I think they give the kind of stereoscopic vision necessary to hold the entire hologram of what's happening in your mind. The old paradigm is gone.” . . . “Shamanism is about shape shifting. Shamanism is about doing phenomenology with a tool kit that works.” . . . “I think psychedelics are sort of like doing calisthenics in preparation for the marathon at the end of time.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 348-Metz: "Entheogens and Plant Medicines"
item.description: Today's program features the 2012 Palenque Norte Lecture that Dr. Natalie Metz gave at the Burning Man Festival. Natalie is a Licensed Naturopathic Doctor in private practice in San Francisco. In this engaging talk, and through interaction with her audience, Dr. Natalie discusses some of the foods, medicines, and poisons that we obtain from plants and helps us to better realize what a deep connection we humans have to the plant world.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 347-TMcKenna: "This counts, somehow it matters"
item.description: Terence McKenna returns once again, this time in some opening remarks during the Friday introduction session of a weekend workshop that was held late in 1994. Early on he says, “Our best efforts are nothing more than half-completed stories told around the campfire. We don't actually know what our predicament is. We are up against a phenomenon which we can barely bring into focus in our cognitive sphere, and it's the phenomenon of our own existence.” . . . and it only gets better from there.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 346-Damer: "Critical Intelligence"
item.description: In today's podcast Bruce Damer takes the 2012 Palenque Norte audience at the Burning Man Festival on a far flung journey into what he calls his practice of "global multi-cultural, multi-ethnic, multi-technic shamanism" where you "put yourself on the shelf" and dive deeply into the worlds of Pentagon think tanks, NASA mission designers, the tribal cultures of Pakistan, the Swiss, Egyptologists, IT professionals, and Christian Evangelicals, to come back with the true alchemical gold. It's an interesting trip.

item.title: 345-TMcKenna: "Transhuman Encounters"
item.description: Today we again travel back in time, almost 30 years, and join Terence McKenna for a few thoughts about transhuman encounters, or, as he likes to call it “alien love”. In case you are thinking that this is just another one of his journeys into the realm of UFOs, abductions, and the like, you may be surprised at the approach to these topics that he takes in this lecture. It isn't only aliens that Terence talks about. He also covers his main beat, psychedelics, and says: “I don't think that mass drug taking is a good idea. But I think that we must have a deputized minority, a shamanic professional class if you will, whose job is to bring ideas out of the deep black water and show them off to the rest of us and perform for our culture some of the cultural functions that shaman perform in pre-literate cultures.” He goes on to say, “You have to take seriously the notion that understanding the universe is your responsibility, because the only understanding of the universe that will be useful to you is your understanding.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 344-TMcKenna: "A Global Cultural Crisis"
item.description: In today's podcast we hear once again from Terence McKenna, who proposes that the 20th century appeared to reflect the state of chaos in Europe during the Renaissance only on a global scale this time. He then goes on to relate his views to the Gaian Hypothesis. A few of the ideas he floats in this talk include: “I think there is a global commonality of understanding coming into being. And it is not necessarily fostered by institutions.” . . . “If I had to pick an ontological vision that was compatible with what I think these drugs are about, and with what I think is trying to happen, I would pick Taoism.” . . . “I'm proposing on one level that hallucinogens be thought of as almost as social pheromones that regulate the rate at which language develops, and therefore regulate human culture generally.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 343-Oak: "Developing a Community Tea House Model"
item.description: Today we hear from civil rights activist and the founder of the Women's Visionary Congress in her 2012 Palenque Norte Lecture at the Burning Man Festival. Anyone who is feeling that they are “out there at the end of the line” may find great encouragement in what Annie has to say as she tells the story of her own unique journey through life. And for the psychedelic community she has these powerful words, “We're not the counter-culture. We are the culture, and we need to make the culture visible.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 342-Grey: "Psychedelic Family Business"
item.description: Today's program features the 2012 Palenque Norte Lecture that Allyson and Alex Grey gave at the Burning Man Festival. In addition to urging (and motivating) artists to follow their dreams, they also give significant practical advice based upon their own experiences, including the ongoing work with COSM. As Alex says, “If it's a psychedelic family business, then you've got to consider the 'top line' [as contrasted with 'the bottom line']. What's the top line? The top line is: You have one unique life, and what do you love to do? What do you want to spend your life doing? What is the highest impact you can have on the world in a positive way?”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 341-DMcKenna: "Ayahuasca Research Report"
item.description: Today's talk features Dennis McKenna in a June 1984 presentation of his research concerning ayahuasca. This is one of the first, if not the first, public presentation of Dennis' early work involving this sacred medicine. For most of the last 33 years, ayahuasca has been one of the major preoccupations of his professional life, and he is considered one of the world's leading scientific experts in this field. As Dennis says in a recent article in The Journal of Psychoactive Drugs: “In that time, I have written extensively on the botany, chemistry, and pharmacology of ayahuasca, on its potential therapeutic uses, and on the need for more, and more rigorous, scientific and clinical investigations of this remarkable plant decoction. Working with colleagues such as Dr. Grob, my good friends Jace Callaway and Dr. Luis Eduardo Luna in Finland, my mentor Dr. Neil Towers, my late and beloved brother Terence, Dr. Glaucus de Souza Brito, and others, to investigate the myriad mysteries of ayahuasca, has been as rich and rewarding an experience as any scientist could ever hope for.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 340-John-Tango: "Visions and Biospheres"
item.category: Bioshpere, Earth Science, environment, culture, science
item.description: Today's podcast features another of the 2012 Palenque Norte Lectures that were held at the Burning Man Festival. The speakers are John Allen and Tango Parrish Snyder, both of whom have been involved in many large-scale Earth Science projects, including Biosphere 2. In his presentation, John makes a strong plea for all of us to gain a better understanding of not just our own local ecosystems, but of the Earth's entire biosphere as well. It is a fascinating talk and is followed by an interesting Q&A session.

item.title: 339-McKenna: "A Necessary Chaos"
item.description: Today I'm going to play a little audio collage of Terence McKenna that comes from a radio interview and one other recording. Some of my favorite Terence quotes from this program are: “I think it's the sheer power of the hallucinogens that puts people off. You either love them or you hate them, and that's because they dissolve world views. And if you like the experience of having your entire ontological structure disappear out from under you, if you think that's a thrill, you'll probably love psychedelics.” . . . and . . . “We can no longer have forbidden areas of the human mind, or cultural machinery. We have taken upon ourselves the acquisition of so much power that we now must understand what we are. We cannot travel much further with the definitions of man that we inherit from the Judeo-Christian tradition. We need to truly explore the problem of consciousness.” . . . and . . . “Capitalism is a gun pointed at the head of global civilization.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 338-Stolarof: "A Tribute to Myron Stolaroff"
item.description: A tribute to the author, engineer, and psychedelic researcher, Myron Stolaroff. In addition to some reminiscences by Lorenzo, this podcast features selections from various Myron Stolaroff podcasts.

item.title: 337-McKenna: "The World Could Be Anything"
item.description: In this, my last podcast of 2012, I thought it would be fun to hear a little more from Terence McKenna. As always, there is always something new to think about after listening to one of his lectures. Here are just two brief quotes from this talk: “And the whole schtick of the psychedelic experience, I think, is reclaim immediate experience, realize that you out vote all parliaments, police forces, and major newspapers on the planet because, who knows, they may be illusions.” . . . “The world could be anything, you know, It could be a solid state matrix of some sort. It could be an illusion. It could be a dream. I mean it really could be a dream.”

item.title: 336-Pinchbeck: "2012 Re-visioned"
item.description: Since today (the day I'm recording and posting this podcast) is the 2012 Winter Solstice, I'm going to feature my friend Daniel Pinchbeck as our guest speaker. As you know, Daniel wrote a book titled “2012: The Return of Quetzalcoatl”, also, he is widely known as a speaker and writer about many things psychedelic and esoteric. However, I know him best as a fellow alumnus of the Entheobotany Seminars at Palenque, where Terence McKenna and his merry band of psychonauts would hold forth each January. In this talk, one that he gave at the Palenque Norte lectures during this year's Burning Man festival, Daniel follows the format of other psychedelic luminaries and lets the audience guide the direction of the lecture through their questions. Among other topics that Daniel covers are 2012, consciousness, the Occupy Movement, and possibilities for the future.

As you know, Daniel wrote a book titled “2012: The Return of Quetzalcoatl”, also, he is widely known as a speaker and writer about many things psychedelic and esoteric. However, I know him best as a fellow alumnus of the Entheobotany Seminars at Palenque, where Terence McKenna and his merry band of psychonauts would hold forth each January. In this talk, one that he gave at the Palenque Norte lectures during this year's Burning Man festival, Daniel follows the format of other psychedelic luminaries and lets the audience guide the direction of the lecture through their questions. Among other topics that Daniel covers are 2012, consciousness, the Occupy Movement, and possibilities for the future.

item.title: 335-McKenna: "Is There Any Reason to Hope?"
item.description: Today's podcast features a talk given by Terence McKenna at the legendary Megatripolis Club in London during the Summer of 1994. He is introduced to a somewhat raucous crowd by the proprietor of the club, Fraser Clark. In this wide-ranging talk, McKenna begins by saying, “The smart people who are straight are involved in simply the media management of what has turned into a slow apocalypse, spreading starvation, exacerbated class differences, toxified agriculture, so forth and so on. I don't believe the Establishment thinks there are solutions. Their policy is basically the management of panic, which is hardly a forward moving approach to the adventure of human civilization.” Later, as only Terence could, he cries out, “Let's not underrate cannabis, for cryin' out loud. Cannabis should be the glue of the community!”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 334-Wallace: "The Alchemy of Cacao"
item.description: Today we feature Brian Wallace's 2012 Palenque Norte Lecture at the Burning Man Festival. Brian, who has been a community organizer for MAPS and other organizations, is also expert on the cacao plant. Originally, Brian titled this talk “The Entheobotany of Cacao”, however, I decided to change the title to better reflect the wide-ranging discussion of a little-understood, but extremely important, plant. This is about significantly more than chocolate. Following Brian's talk I play a short segment about the work of Occupy Sandy and close with a song sent in from some fellow saloners, The Chooks, it is simply titled “Occupy” and is freely available for download via PsychedelicSalon.us.

item.title: 333-Adams: Producing "The Terence McKenna Experience"
item.description: Today we feature the fifth Palenque Norte Lecture of 2012, which was given at the Burning Man Festival. This talk features the filmmaker Ken Adams, who was a neighbor, friend, and collaborator of Terence McKenna in their search for new ways of explaining the psychedelic experience. Ken is the producer/director of a new, and experimental, film titled “The Terence McKenna Experience” which features never before seen and heard raps by Terence. . . . Following the Ken Adams talk, I feature three short sound clips from the Occupy Movement: 1) Occupy Atlanta Homes; 2) Rolling Jubilee; and 3) Occupy Sandy.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 332-Shaw: "Living in the Exile Nation"
item.description: Today we feature another of the 2012 Palenque Norte Lectures that were given at the Burning Man Festival. This talk is by author, lecturer, and drug war authority, Charles Shaw, who learned the truth about the War on Drugs from the people who are most being oppressed by this war. As he says, “For the lower classes, the poorer classes, which generally in this country are people of color, drug laws have always been used as a way to control them.” And he goes on to say, “But what they're trying to stop more than anything is ideas. Because what it is is a war of ideas. . . . It's no secret that psychedelics change consciousness. It's no secret that they're revolutionary. . . . The true revolutionary leaders, I think, are going to be the ones who figure out how to not go in the street and how to disseminate the revolution by other means.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 331-Hewlett: "Understanding the Default Process of Consciousness"
item.description: Today's podcast features the third in the series of the 2012 Palenque Norte Lectures at the Burning Man festival. The speaker is Dr. Brian Hewlett and he titled his talk "An Algorithm of Human Consciousness and Implications for Artificial Intelligence". As you can see, I have re-titled the talk “Understanding the Default Process of Consciousness” to better fit with some of his closing remarks which included: “If you understand the default process of your consciousness, and you work with that default process and start to pay attention to that process, then you can actually start to manipulate the process, just like you can manipulate any process that you understand.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 330-Maddy: "The Politics of Knowledge in the Psychedelic Sciences"
item.description: Today we feature the second of the 2012 Palenque Norte Lectures at the Burning Man Festival. The talk was given by Dr. Michelle (Maddy) Corbin whose doctoral dissertation is titled “Spirituality in the laboratory: Negotiating the politics of knowledge in the psychedelic sciences”. Among her many insightful observations is this interesting thought: “And because it came through a chemical that allowed them to study it, they began to engage with spirituality in a way that was historically unprecedented. I argue that [psychedelics] are a doorway through which spirituality entered the scientific laboratory in a way that it usually doesn't.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 329-Sage: "Vision Mapping for the Golden Age"
item.description: This podcast is the first from the 2012 Palenque Norte Lectures at the Burning Man Festival. After an introduction to the series by Bruce Damer we feature the extraordinary visionary artist Amanda Sage. While her talk follows the exciting path that her life has taken, it is also a remarkable word-painting of a future that has already begun, particularly among the world wide artistic and dance communities. This is one of the most hopeful and forward-looking presentations yet to be featured in the salon.

item.title: 328-Hancock: "In Praise of Ayahuasca"
item.description: “We ought to be able, in a responsible society, as responsible adults, to gain good information. If we want to experiment with our consciousness we should be able to gain good and reliable information easily. Instead it's very difficult. We have to go underground. We have to stay out of the mainstream if we want to learn about ayahuasca.” And, “What ayahuasca does is to allow us to make accessible to our senses areas of reality that are normally off limits to us. I believe that those are real, not fiction of the brain. What the shamans call 'the spirit world', what quantum physicists might call parallel universes or parallel dimensions, I think they exist.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 327-Phillips: "Jesus, Aliens, and Ayahuasca"
item.description: Today's podcast features a talk given by Jonathan Talat Phillips in Vancouver sometime earlier this year. In it, Jonathan tells the story of how, after a devastating loss as counter cultural activist, he embarked on a mystical initiation involving underground ayahuasca ceremonies, kundalini awakenings, DMT cowboys, shapeshifting extraterrestrials at Burning Man, miraculous healings, and an international movement trailblazing visionary ways to help our planet in crisis. Along the way he uncovers the lost rites of the Christian mystery schools and secret “electric” messages for personal and global transformation. . . . Jonathan is the author of “The Electric Jesus: The Healing Journey of a Contemporary Gnostic.” He co-founded the cutting edge web-magazine Reality Sandwich and The Evolver Network, coordinating 40+ regional Evolver communities. He is a religion blogger for "The Huffington Post," the creator of “The Ayahuasca Monologues: Tales of the Spirit Vine,” a Reiki Master and Bioenergetic Healer.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 326-Krishnamurti: "Avoiding the Pitfall of Words"
item.description: This podcast features part one of a six part talk given my J. Krishnamurti in October 1966 at New York City. As he points out, “The crisis is not in the outward technological advancement, but rather in the way we think, and the way we live, and the way we feel. I think that is where a revolution must take place.”

item.title: 325-McKenna: "Cauldron Chemistry"
item.description: Today's podcast features an interview with Terence McKenna that Elizabeth Gips conducted at Terence's home sometime in 1985. And while it includes Terence's thoughts about synthetic vs. natural hallucinogens, my favorite parts of this talk deal with the topic of “cauldron chemistry”, including one of the all-time classic McKenna quotes, "I'm not sure pig intestines is the second ingredient...".

item.title: 324-Damer: "Esalen 2012 Redux"
item.description: Today's program consists of ten separate pieces from a June 2012 workshop at the Esalen Institute, eight of which are by Bruce Damer. Here are the titles that Bruce has given to these short talks: --Are we all becoming autistic astronauts? --On our dual bonobo and chimp nature --The things I loved about Terence --Esalen @ 50 --"Procreate only once" (and we will have a future) --The wellspring of human consciousness --Terence's greatest Rap: Its all about Love, and where to now, Butterfly Hunter? Following that we will be hearing the two closing segments of the workshop. The first is the “Rap for Terence” by Earth Girl and following that comes Galen Brandt singing her tribute to Terence titled “Aho Terence floating in the sky”.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 323-Lorenzo: "Searching for a New Paradise Myth"
item.description: This podcast features the final community discussions at the June 2012 Esalen workshop led by Lorenzo and Bruce Damer. Among the topics discussed were: . . . Creating a new myth for our community . . . The genesis of the Occupy Movement . . . Are psychedelic “mutants” among us? . . . Cultural Creatives . . . Freeing our food supply from money . . . Timebanks . . . What the mushroom has to say about the future . . . The Importance of myth . . . Developing a “Medicine Circle” app . . . Building new cultures through shared global experiences . . . The 'superfood' revolution and our connection to the Earth . . . Indra's Net . . . The Temple at the Burning Man Festival

item.title: 322-Leary: "The Evolution of Intelligence"
item.description: In this 1983 talk, given on his 63rd birthday, Dr. Timothy Leary covers a wide range of topics, including his own take on the Adam and Eve story in the Bible. In addition to his normally provocative statements, such as, “Reagan is a certifiable lunatic,” Dr. Leary also points out a fact of life back then that is even more intense today, “And that's one of the things that is kind of amazing today, the junk information that we're being inundated with, the cloud, the atmosphere, the smog of disinformation.” He also gives some very sound advice about drugs, “The sensible thing to do about drugs is this, get yourself a really good dealer.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 321-Lorenzo: "A Discussion About Psychedelics"
item.description: Today's podcast features the next installment of the workshop that Bruce Damer and Lorenzo led at the Esalen Institute in June of 2012. The majority of this program features comments by some of the workshop's participants who bring up topics that include: Heroic doses; Body load with psychedelics; Techniques for using psychedelics; What exactly is the psychedelic state; The perfect answer when a cop asks, “Were are you at, buddy?”; The re-introduction of psychedelics to our species; How do we tell the psychedelic story; The Occupy Movement and the banking system; The need for a parallel system of money
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 320-Lorenzo: “Occupy Yourself”
item.description: Today's podcast features the next installment of the workshop that Bruce Damer and I led at the Esalen Institute near Big Sur, California in mid-June 2012. This segment contains the commentary from participants in the workshop immediately after the “Deep Dive into the Mind of McKenna” that was featured in Podcast 316 and which has been temporarily removed from the Net. While the title of this talk may indicate that it is another podcast about the Occupy Movement, but that isn't actually the case, although the movement is referred to in part.

item.title: 319-McKenna: "The Voynich Manuscript"
item.description: According to Wikipedia, the Voynich Manuscript has been described as “the world's most mysterious manuscript”, and so far its secret code has never been broken . . . including attempts by top U.S. Government cytologists. And this is the subject of today's talk by Terence McKenna from an April 1983 lecture.

item.title: 318-McKenna: "Psilocybin and the Sands of Time"
item.description: This is the second tape in the Paul Herbert Collection of the words of Terence McKenna, and as far as I can tell, it hasn't been posted on the Net before. The title of the talk as shown on the cassette tape from which it came is “Psilocygin and the Sands of Time”, however, that first word may be a misspelling of the word 'psilocybin'. The recording was made in December of 1982 and the event was a “SEN Interview” at the Esalen Institute near Big Sur, California. Like most McKenna talks, this one is also packed full of interesting ideas, such as: “On these matters of specific fact, like is the mushroom an extraterrestrial and that sort of thing, I haven't the faintest idea. The mushroom itself is such a mercurial, elusive, Zen sort of personality that I never believe a word it says. I simply entertain its notions and try and sort through them, and I found that to be the most enriching approach to it.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 317-McKenna: “New and Old Maps of Hyperspace”
item.description: This is the first of what I am calling the Paul Herbert Collection of the words of Terence McKenna. The tape's label reads: “Terence McKenna: NEW AND OLD MAPS OF HYPERSPACE ISC Lecture November 1982 Berkeley.” The complete collection consists of over 160 high quality recordings of Terence McKenna lectures that were recorded by Paul Herbert. Over the course of the next few years I will be podcasting this entire collection in the order in which they were recorded. This means that there will be a few McKenna lectures that will be repeated here in the salon, as a few of them had already been available in many places. However, there is a good deal of new material here, and over the next two years I suspect we will hear many new gems from the lips of the bard McKenna.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.itunes:author: Lorenzo
item.itunes:summary: This is the first of what I am calling the Paul Herbert Collection of the words of Terence McKenna. The tape's label reads: “Terence McKenna: NEW AND OLD MAPS OF HYPERSPACE ISC Lecture November 1982 Berkeley.” The complete collection consists of over 160 high quality recordings of Terence McKenna lectures that were recorded by Paul Herbert. Over the course of the next few years I will be podcasting this entire collection in the order in which they were recorded. This means that there will be a few McKenna lectures that will be repeated here in the salon, as a few of them had already been available in many places. However, there is a good deal of new material here, and over the next two years I suspect we will hear many new gems from the lips of the bard McKenna.

item.title: 316-Damer: "A Deep Dive Into the Mind of McKenna"
item.description: This program is a recording of part of a live event at the Esalen Institute near Big Sur, California. The workshop, titled “Terence McKenna: Beyond 2012” and was led by Bruce Damer and Lorenzo Hagerty. This specific recording took place on Saturday morning, June 16th and consists of Bruce's “deep dive” into the mind of McKenna. It begins with Bruce's “Ode to Terence” and is followed by Bruce's readings of parts of the soon-to-be published book by Terence's brother, Dennis . . . the book's title: “Brotherhood of the Screaming Abyss”.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 315-Leary: “In a German Salon 1983" Part 3
item.description: Today we conclude a three part series featuring Dr. Timothy Leary speaking somewhere in Germany in 1983. One of the features of this talk is his frank discussion of ketamine and of Dr. John Lilly. And then he goes on to give the following advice to the Baby Boomer generation: “Your generation is a sinking ship. So the intelligent thing to do is to jump ship.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 314-Leary: “In a German Salon 1983" Part 2
item.description: Today we pick up where we left off in my previous podcast with the good Doctor Timothy Leary holding forth in a very small group setting somewhere in Germany. As near as I can tell, this private salon was held sometime in 1983. One of the comments he makes in this talk is he thinks that each generation born after World War II may actually be an entirely new species of human. And while this may sound quite radical, particularly when you consider that he made this comment in 1983, there is a recent TED talk by Juan Enriquez titled “Will our kids be a different species?” I have linked to it in the program notes for this podcast and highly recommend that you give it a listen as well.

item.title: 313-Leary: “In a German Salon 1983" Part 1”
item.description: Today's podcast features another recording from the Dr. Timothy Leary archive. As best I can tell, it was recorded at a small salon somewhere in Germany in 1983 or so. As is often the case with Dr. Leary, a wide variety of topics was covered in a relatively short time. The notation on the tape from which this talk came listed the following topics as being included (to one degree or another): Humor; John Lilly; HANDS ON; Turn on, drop out & take over; Stage 12; Bodymanagement; Self reliance, Purpose of Life. And in one way or another he managed to squeeze them all in to a single hour of recording.

item.title: 312-Moglan: “Occupy the Internet”
item.description: Today's podcast features one of the most important lectures that I have played here in the salon. It is a talk that Dr. Eben Moglan gave on May 22, 2012 at the Freedom to Connect conference. In this talk Dr. Moglen very clearly describes the imminent threat that governments and large corporations pose to not only our freedom to use the Internet as we choose, but to the further evolution of human consciousness itself. As he says in this talk, “The Network, as it stands now, is an extraordinary platform for enhanced social control. Very rapidly, and with no apparent remorse, the two largest governments on Earth, that of the United States of America and the People's Republic of China, have adopted essentially the identical points of view. A robust social graph connecting government to everybody, and the exhaustive date mining of society, is both governments' fundamental policy with respect to their different forms of what they both refer to, or think of, as 'stability maintenance'. . . . We need, 'we' who understand what is happening, need to be very vocal about that.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 311-Lorenzo: "The Spirit of the Internet"
item.description: Today I'm playing a recording of a talk that I gave in March of 2001 at The Inside Edge, a Southern California association of cultural creatives. The topic was some of the themes in my book, “The Spirit of the Internet: Speculations on the Evolution of Global Consciousness”. One of the more controversial aspects of this talk is my comparison of a deep Internet experience with a psychedelic experience. . . . Also included in this podcast is some discussion of the growing student strike in Quebec and the mounting student loan debt bubble here in the U.S.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 310-McKenna: “Introduction to the Valley of Novelty Workshop”
item.description: At long last I am finally getting around to podcasting the first session of the Valley of Novelty workshop that Terence McKenna led at Omega Institute in upstate New York on the evening of July 31, 1998. I posted the rest of this workshop several years ago, beginning in podcast 027. In today's program you will hear how Terence often began his workshops, by going around the circle and letting the attendees say a little something. And sometimes Terence would jump in and comment on what they had just brought up. Unfortunately, most of the comments by the attendees wasn't picked up by the single microphone in the front of the room. So I deleted any sections of seeming quiet but left in any comments that Terence made, including his opening and closing remarks.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 309-McKenna: “In Praise of Psychedelics” Part 2
item.description: This program includes the end of the Terence McKenna lecture that we were listening to in the previous podcast. And that is followed by a question and answer session, which ends with Terence giving one of the most impassioned pleas for psychonaughts to “come out of the closet” that I have ever heard him (or anyone else) give. . . . And a couple of interesting Terence McKenna quotes from this podcast include: “Anyone who loves adventure, and who loves life, and who loves the experience of being, has an obligation, I think, to explore this [the psychedelic realm]. It's as much a part of your identity as your sexuality, your ancestral history, or your hopes and fears. And to ignore it is to choose to play with less than a full deck. Don't do that. Play with a full deck!” . . . and “People didn't care for the Holocaust, that was a moral outrage, but the policies of the Roman Catholic Church push more people into early death, disease, and poverty than the Holocaust ever did. And yet, they're perfectly free to run their bingo games and appear among us. Why? They should have to answer for this outrage.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 308-McKenna: “In Praise of Psychedelics” Part 1
item.description: Today's program features the first part of a two hour lecture given by Terence McKenna in early February, 1994. The official title of this talk is “Speaking the Unspeakable”, however, after listening to the first part of it I decided to change the title to something that seemed, to me, more appropriate. A few of my favorite quotes from this talk include: “The contradiction that history confronts us with is a deeper exploration of the psychedelic experience. And the psychedelic experience is something incredibly alien to the Western mind. It is, in fact, taboo.” . . . “The psychedelic experience is not built in to your biology the way orgasm, or sleep, or hunger, or something like that is. It's a physiological option that involves forming a symbiotic relationship with a plant.” . . . “Science has steered us deeply into the notion that nature is soulless and spiritless. And the practice of this idea has led us to the brink of catastrophe, global and species and ecological catastrophe.” . . . “Psychedelics are catalysts for the human imagination. That very simply is what they are.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 307-Various: “Palenque Entheobotany Seminars Remembered”
item.description: Today's program features, first of all, a conversation between Matt Pallamary and Wild Bill, who begin by reminiscing about the legendary Palenque Entheobotany Seminars, but who then go on to other wild tales, some of which may actually be true. After that is the first of our long-awaited Global Trialogues in which Bruce Damer answers a question from a young man in Australia.

item.title: 306-McKenna: “Terence McKenna & Ram Das in Prague”
item.description: Today's podcast features interviews conducted by Terence McKenna with cultural anthropologist Angeles Arrien and cultural icon Ram Das. The conversations took place in June of 1992 while they were attending a conference in Prague. After first discussing a few of the more esoteric aspects of the psychedelic experience, Ram Das and Terence reminisce about the Sixties and why their vision may not have succeeded. Among the interesting quotes are where Ram Das, speaking of the Sixties, said, “The fact that they noticed us was because we were busy making statements, instead of just being it.” Later, Terence McKenna says, “To me, the most amazing the most amazing transformation in my lifetime is not the revolution of the Sixties but the counter revolution of the Seventies, where they managed to put the cuckoo clock back together again.”
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 305-Damer: “Conservatives Confront the Ideas of Occupy: A Radical Remake of America”
item.description: Today I return to an all-Occupy program and feature an interview that Bruce Damer gave to KSCO radio in Santa Cruz, California on November 19, 2011. While there are some rather interesting comments by listeners who called in to this very conservative talk-radio station, the focus of the interview was a discussion of Bruce Damer's proposal, echoing the advice of Thomas Jefferson, that the citizens of the U.S. hold a new constitutional convention and bring about a radical remake of the country.

item.title: 304-Leary: “Timothy Leary and Jerry Brown in 1995”
item.description: This week as a follow-up to my previous podcast, which was primarily 'about' Dr. Timothy Leary. So this week I am playing an interview 'with' Timothy Leary that was conducted in October of 1995. Following that I play a short audio piece that was from an NPR program in 1996 that aired just a few weeks before Dr. Leary's death in May of 1996.

item.title: 303-Harcourt-Smith: “The Arrest and Imprisonment of Dr. Timothy Leary”
item.description: Today's program features a lengthy interview with Joanna Harcourt-Smith, who was the companion of Dr. Timothy Leary during the period when he was kidnapped at an airport in Afghanistan by the U.S. Government. Following that, Joanna was the only outside contact that Timothy Leary was permitted during the time he was in custody. This is a fascinating story of one of the most turbulent times in U.S. History told by a woman who was there.

item.title: 302-Fadiman: "The Psychedelic Explorer's Guide"
item.description: This may be the most important podcast that I have done so far. In it you will hear from Dr. James Fadiman, a man who has been at the forefront of psychedelic research since the Sixties. In this interview, conducted by Matt Pallamary, Jim not only talks about his new book, “The Psychedelic Explorer's Guide: Safe, Therapeutic, and Sacred Journeys”, he also provides a significant amount of information, both new and old, that hopefully will never be lost, as it is of critical importance to the evolution of human consciousness

item.title: 301-Lorenzo: “Terence McKenna: Beyond 2012” Part 4
item.description: In this, the concluding episode of recordings from the workshop titled “Terence McKenna: Beyond 2012” and led by Bruce Damer and Lorenzo, we hear Bruce's final presentation in which he begins by taking us on a mental voyage around our solar system. From there he tells a fascinating story of his meeting with a somewhat dodgy character who convincingly explained that, although it may appear that way at times, there actually is no cabal secretly controlling human affairs. Following that begins an interesting Q & A session. . . . In the Occupy segment of the podcast I ponder over the pros and cons of the Black Bloc tactics that have become somewhat controversial lately.

item.title: 300-Lorenzo: “Terence McKenna: Beyond 2012” Part 3
item.description: Today I pick up with the next part of a workshop that was held on January 28, 2012 titled “Terence McKenna: Beyond 2012”. This section features my second presentation of the day in which I attempted to explain why I think that the Occupy Movement is so important. And in the second half of this podcast I play two edited audio clips of the respected journalist Chris Hedges who expresses some of his ideas about the Occupy Movement and it's importance.

item.title: 299-Damer: “Terence McKenna: Beyond 2012” Part 2
item.description: In today's podcast we pick up with the next part of a workshop that was held on January 28, 2012 titled “Terence McKenna: Beyond 2012”. This section features Bruce Damer, who begins with his “Ode to Terence” and follows with a wide-ranging question and answer session. In the Occupy segment I begin with a recap of what went down in Washington, D.C. the day of the eviction from McPherson Square. The voice you'll hear is that of Nate, who streams a live video feed on Ustream.tv that is called OccupyAir, and this is his recap of the day's events. Also, I play a series of short audio clips. The first one is of a young man from San Diego who was speaking at the General Assembly that was held in the middle of K Street in Washington the evening after the McPhearson eviction. Following him is a bit about the Department of Homeland Security, which now includes a national secret police force, in case you missed that announcement, and we now learn that the DHS is now monitoring journalists and bloggers in a blatant attempt to keep the press away from the occupy actions. Next up is part of an interview with journalist Chris Hedges, who you've heard from on several occasions here in these podcasts already. In this clip Chris will be talking about some of the ideas he put forth in his book, “Empire of Illusion”. And while this segment also ends with a call to the barricades from Chris Hedges in different interview, between those two Hedges segments I play a three minute pep talk that Tony Benn gave to some of the occupiers in London the other day.

item.title: 298-Lorenzo: “Terence McKenna: Beyond 2012” Part 1
item.description: This is the first in a series of three podcasts that will feature the presentations by Bruce Damer and Lorenzo at the January 28, 2012 workshop, which was held in the Los Angeles area. Today's segment includes Lorenzo's opening talk and comments from the attendees as well as a few remarks by Bruce. Following that part of the podcast is the Occupy Movement update, which features a conversation between Lawrence Lessig and Chris Hedges. During the course of their conversation they debate the relative merits of pushing for a Constitutional Convention verses non-violent civil disobedience. Also included is a sound bite from one of OccupyFreedomLA's live video feeds in which a speaker addresses the actions now being taken by those who are suffering from the foreclosure epidemic that is facing so many people in the U.S.

Today's segment includes Lorenzo's opening talk and comments from the attendees as well as a few remarks by Bruce. Following that part of the podcast is the Occupy Movement update, which features a conversation between Lawrence Lessig and Chris Hedges. item.title: 297-Various: “Tribute to Robert Anton Wilson”
item.description: The featured audio that I'm going to play in this podcast is part of a two-CD collection produced by Joe Matheny and given to the salon to podcast by the distributor, The Original Falcon Press, which you can find via originalfalcon.com. There isn't time to hear the entire collection, which is titled “Robert Anton Wilson Remembered”, but I've selected a representative sampling that I think gives a really well-rounded picture of this incredible mind as well as giving us a better idea of the wonderful person that his friends called Bob and the rest of us called RAW. The voices you will here are of: Douglas Rushkoff Antero Alli Tiffany Lee Brown – don't know where she stands on OWS, but her talk sounds right out of the movement to me Tiffany is followed by David Jay Brown author of the “Mavericks of the Mind” and “Mavericks of Medicine” books and the closing comments are by the producer and friend of the salon Joseph Matheny For the Occupy Segment, I first play a few minutes that I've taken from a three hour interview that Chris Hedges gave on CSPAN 2 on the first day of this year, and in it you will hear this Pulitzer Prize winning journalist explain how corporate personhood isn't just a threat to American Democracy, it is a threat to humanity itself. . . . Following that, I play a short speech for you that Senator Bernie Sanders gave on the Senate floor as he introduced an amendment to the U.S. Constitution that will strip personhood from corporations. After those two kind of heavy duty pieces. I lighten it up with a two minute clip of country music star Willie Nelson and his wife reading a poem that he wrote about the Occupy Movement. Finally, I close with a song that was written and is sung by a young man from Salt Lake City named Noel. And this is from a YouTube video I found where Noel was singing on Day 1 of the Occupy Salt Lake City street theater

item.title: 296-McKenna: “The World and It's Double” Part 2
item.description: Today's podcast is a continuation of the lecture that I played in the podcast just previous to this one. And at one point in this talk, Terence McKenna says, “Let those who talk to the elves find each other and band together.” While that would be a great segue into another Occupy Movement podcast, I'm instead going to do just the opposite. Originally, I planned on splitting the talk I'm about to play into two more segments, each followed by another Occupy update. But after previewing it, I decided that it would be best to just play the remainder of this talk that Terence McKenna gave sometime in 1993, and I think he gave it on several occasions which most likely each differ slightly in content, but he called this series of lectures “The World and Its Double”. Here are a few Terence McKenna quotes from this lecture: “There are old psychedelicists and bold psychedelicists, but there are no old, bold psychedelicists.” … “[DMT] is a secret of such magnitude that it's inconceivable how it has ever been kept.” … and “We all want our children to be well-adjusted, unfortunately there is nothing to be well-adjusted too. So that's a real problem.”
