item.title: 209-Huxley: "An Audio Collage of Aldous Huxley"
item.description: I've called this an audio collage for want of a better description. In this podcast you will hear not only what others thought of Aldous Huxley, you will hear him conversing in both interview format and in a more conversational setting. The range of topics covered in this collection of Huxley sound bites including a discussion of the arts in general, James Joyce, the best method for discussing philosophy including an example of how he went about creating his work, what he thinks about the supernatural, our lack of great symbols right now, and his involvement with psychedelic substances.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 208-Nadelmann: "It's Time To End The War on Drugs"
item.description: In this November 2009 presentation at a PATH event in San Diego, Ethan Nadelmann, founder and executive director of the Drug Policy Alliance, gives not just facts and figures, but also includes a stirring call to bring reason into the debate about ending the War on People who use non-prescription drugs. ... As he says, "That we are each sovereign over our own minds and bodies, that is the core principle that we have to keep putting out there."

item.title: 207-Various Speakers: "A Tribute to Alan Watts"
item.description: Today we begin with a short clip of Alan Watts speaking about human consciousness. Then we go to a little gathering at Dr. John Lilly's home, where he, Laura Huxley, and others give tribute to the life of Alan Watts a few months after his death.

item.title: 206-McKenna: "Appreciating Imagination" Part 6
item.description: In this final installment of a 1997 Terence McKenna workshop about Appreciating Imagination, he comes up with quite a few interesting thoughts, such as: "I think that in service to the principle of parsimony, preferring the simplest explanation, these things [beings encountered in DMT space] must be human souls." ... and ... "If you're living right, your life should get just more and more baroque, beautiful, complicated, mysterious ... and then you die."
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 205-McKenna: "Appreciating Imagination" Part 5 (Timewave)
item.description: In this next to last part of a 1997 Terence McKenna workshop dealing with the imagination, Terence takes us for a ride on his Timewave hypothesis. ... At one point he says, "I do entertain the idea that we may each have our own Timewave, sort of following the model of astrology." ... Then near the end of this session we hear him say, "The whole thing [Timewave hypothesis] smacks of the impossible. It's even pushed me toward the idea that maybe this is not actually a reality. We're trapped, or I'm trapped. I don't know if you're trapped. But we're in some kind of piece of fiction. It's like a Phillip K. Dick deal, you know. We're in some kind of simulacrum, and the clue to the fact that it's a simulacrum is this impossible idea [the Timewave]. And so the point of the idea is not to believe it, but to use it as a wedge to fight our way out of this labyrinth and back to whatever reality we were in before we fell into this situation. Something like that."
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 204-McKenna: "Appreciating Imagination" Part 4
item.description: In part four of the Terence McKenna workshop about imagination he discusses the ego, Novelty Theory, and the possibility that time is not uniform. As he says, "The Timewave is not occult, but it is not science as we have done it these past 500 years, because it assumes that one of our primary intuitions is actually true; the intuition that every moment is unique [time is not uniform]. It treats that as the central starting point for an entirely new metaphysics of being." ... "The way you investigate time is by moving inward, by investigating metabolism. The human body is a knot in time." ... Also included is part of a conversation with Allan Lundell, Nick Herbert and few friends.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 203-McKenna: "Appreciating Imagination" Part 3
item.description: In this third podcast of Terence McKenna's workshop on imagination, he picks up the pace and speaks to a dozen or more new topics. Not only does he explain what he calls 'McKenna's Five Percent Rule', he also gives us McKenna's Law: "As you advance in social hierarchy the percentage of smart people does not increase. ... Every human situation is bedeviled by morons. No matter how high you rise you're surrounded by fools, and you're lucky if you're not one of them. That's the basic thing to guard against." Plus he returns briefly to his critique of culture and says among other things, "Culture is a simplification and a lie. It's the currency by which fools navigate the world. Smart people get beyond it."
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 202-McKenna: "Appreciating Imagination" Part 2
item.description: Among many other provocative ideas found in this talk is: "The major adventure is to claim your authentic, true being, which is not culturally given to you. The culture will not explain to you how to be a real human being. It will tell you how to be banker, politician, Indian chief, masseuses, actress, whatever, but it will not give you true being." ... Near the end of this podcast we also hear Terence explain his personal ideas about death.

item.title: 201-McKenna: "Appreciating Imagination" Part 1
item.description: Today's podcast is the first in a series from a workshop that Terence McKenna conducted at Esalen Institute in 1994, the focus of which was the human imagination. While he has some interesting thoughts about imagination such as, "Art is like the footprint of where the imagination has been." It was his thought about computers that most people may take away from this first part of the workshop where he also says, "The only difference between computers and drugs is that one is too large to swallow ... and our best people are working on that very problem."
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 200-Various: "A Few Words From Our Elders"
item.description: Since this is my 200th podcast, I thought that it might be nice to hear a selection of sound bites from some of our esteemed elders. So in this program you will hear from Gary Fisher, Sasha Shulgin, Ann Shulgin, Myron Stolaroff, Terence McKenna, Baba Ram Das, and Timothy Leary in a medley of ideas that hopefully will inspire you to strive to become an elder yourself.

item.title: 199-Leary: "Timothy Leary at MIT - 1967"
item.description: In 1967 Dr. Timothy Leary gave a lecture to a group of MIT students in which he said, among other scandalous things: "The educational system, at the present time in the United States does neurological damage to the nervous system and functions as a narcotic, addictive drug." And then he went on to say: "You, the younger generation in particular, have got to drop out, and by drop out I mean all the way. You can't vote, I urge you not to do politics, don't picket, don't get involved in any of these menopausal mind games because it doesn't make any difference."
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 198-McKenna: "NPR Interview - 1999"
item.description: This may be the last radio interview given by the bard Terence McKenna. The date was sometime in March of 1999, just a few weeks before the discovery of his brain tumor. Over a dozen new McKenna quotes from this podcast are posted on our blog at PsychedelicSalon (dot) org, and among the other little gems he at last clearly defines what he means by "the end of history".

item.title: 197-McKenna: "McNature"
item.description: Terence McKenna gave this talk the title of "Nature is the Center of the Mandala", but the cassette it was on had the title of McNature written on it. In any event, here is the Bard McKenna holding forth on the importance of keeping Nature as a focus in our lives. And as always, he has many provocative ideas such as, "Psychedelics are illegal not because a loving government is concerned that you may jump out of a third story window. Psychedelics are illegal because they dissolve opinion structures and culturally laid down models of behavior and information processing. They open you up to the possibility that everything you know is wrong."

item.itunes:author: Lorenzo
item.itunes:summary: Terence McKenna gave this talk the title of "Nature is the Center of the Mandala", but the cassette it was on had the title of McNature written on it. In any event, here is the Bard McKenna holding forth on the importance of keeping Nature as a focus in our lives. And as always, he has many provocative ideas such as, "Psychedelics are illegal not because a loving government is concerned that you may jump out of a third story window. Psychedelics are illegal because they dissolve opinion structures and culturally laid down models of behavior and information processing. They open you up to the possibility that everything you know is wrong."

item.title: 196-Leary: "Timothy Leary vs. Notre Dame"
item.description: In this 1968 lecture at the University of Notre Dame, Dr. Timothy Leary gives the then all-male student body a lesson in alternative thought. Basically, he told them that almost everything they are being taught is tainted with illogic. However, he also said that on the whole he didn't think that most of them were ready to use psychedelics yet, that the experience might be too powerful for them. Among other provocative things that the good doctor had to tell the young Catholic lads was, "Dope is going to be the religion of the future." One can only imagine (with a big smile) how discussions in the religious classrooms on campus went down the next day.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 195-Leary: "The Future of Higher Intelligence" Part 2
item.description: Today we continue listening to a panel discussion from a Psychedelic Conference held at UCSB in 1981. We hear from Robert Anton Wilson and Dr. John Lilly and then we'll hear a clip from a talk that Timothy Leary gave about Dr. Lilly sometime later. Finally, we'll be hearing a song that a German band recorded in 1972 with Dr. Timothy Leary on vocals ... you won't want to miss that one!

item.title: 194-Leary: "The Future of Higher Intelligence" Part 1
item.description: Today's podcast has a full cast of characters. Recorded early in the 1980s at a Psychedelic Conference held at UCSB, we hear a panel consisting of Frank Baron, Andrew Weil, Walter Clark, Robert Anton Wilson, and Paul Krasner that is moderated by Dr. Timothy Leary. Their topic is the future of higher intelligence, and as you can no doubt imagine, a Niagara of interesting ideas flows forth.

item.title: 193-Watts: "The Houseboat Summit - 1967"
item.description: In today's podcast we join Alan Watts, Timothy Leary, Allen Ginsberg, and Gary Snyder for an hour-and-a-half of a conversation held on Watts' houseboat in February of 1967, just a few weeks after the first Human Be-In. While there are any number of interesting tidbits and some fascinating similarities to what is taking place in the world again today, one of the most interesting parts (at least to me) of their conversation is what must have been their first discussion of Dr. Leary's famous, but spontaneous proclamation of, "Turn on, tune in, drop out". If you are a student of Dr. Leary, this is a conversation you won't want to miss. . . . And did I mention that the real star of this show is Alan Watts, who said among other things: "In other words, when there is a game going on that's on a collision course, and that this game obviously is going to lead to total destruction, the only way of getting people out of a bad game is to indicate that the game is no longer interesting. See, we've left this game and it bores us."
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 192-Leary: "Live at the Stone - 1987"
item.description: Think back to the Summer of 1987. Did you own a personal computer then? If so, you were in rare company. And in today's podcast we get to hear Dr. Timothy Leary explain why this new technology was going to revolutionize the world. But he doesn't confine himself to only talking about computers in this presentation that was given at The Stone in San Francisco. ... He also has some amazing stories to tell about the Summer of Love, Abbie Hoffmann, Hunter S. Thompson, and other fun people and events.

item.title: 191-McKenna: "The Ethnobotany of Shamanism" Part 5
item.description: This brings to a conclusion the series of recordings from a Terence McKenna workshop that he led over the weekend of November 5-7, 1988 at the California Institute of Integral Studies (CIIS). One of the more fascinating questions that he answers is, "How do you remember to bring back what you've learned?" And his answer, dealing with state-bounded memory, is something I hadn't thought of before. And like the preivous four programs in this series, Terence again peppers this one with provocative thoughts such as, "This is in fact what shamanism is all about, what the end of history is all about, what psychedelic drugs are all about, we are edge-walking on an ontological transformation of what it means to be human."
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 190-McKenna: "The Ethnobotany of Shamanism" Part 4
item.description: This week we pick up with Terence fielding questions about the visions he sees on various substances and where he thinks they come from. One of his more controversial comments this week may be: "The psychedelic experience is the beginning of the spiritual path. That's why it's not important that yogas claim that they can deliver you the psychedelic experience, because it begins with the psychedelic experience, and then you go from there."
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 189-McKenna: "The Ethnobotany of Shamanism" Part 3
item.description: We continue with a Terence McKenna workshop recorded on the first weekend of November in 1988. The workshop was conducted at the California Institute of Integral Studies in San Francisco. One of the more interesting segments of this talk is that it is one of his clearest public statements regarding the relative merits of natural psychedelics vs. synthetic ones. And his opinion on November 6, 1988 was, "I really think there is a very large distinction between synthetic and naturally occurring drugs." ... He also goes on to say, "I have never felt that the primary use of these things [psychedelic medicines] was to cure what is called in modern parlance neurosis, what I call unhappiness. It isn't for that."

item.title: 188-McKenna: "The Ethnobotany of Shamanism" Part 2
item.description: In today's podcast we pick up where we left off last week with Terence McKenna conducting a workshop in November of 1988. Among other topics, Terence begins his "World Tour of Psychedelic Plants". One of my favorite McKenna quotes from this talk is, "We now have no choice in the matter of business as usual. There will not, apparently, be business as usual." ... and then there is, "Every step into freedom contains within it the potential for greater bondage."

item.title: 187-McKenna: "The Ethnobotany of Shamanism" Part 1
item.description: In today's podcast, which was recorded at a small workshop held at CIIS in San Francisco on November 5, 1988, we hear Terence McKenna talk about some of his boyhood experiences that he feels led him into the world of psychedelic exploration. And then he goes on to briefly describe his years of travel while posing as a butterfly collector, eventually leading him to the Amazon. He then goes on to give his 1988 version of what he thought the psychedelic experience actually was, and he reads the titles of some of his favorite books. Among other McKennisims in this podcast: "What it [investigating psychedelics] really requires is a love of the peculiar, of the weird, the bizarre, the étrange, the freaky and unimaginable."
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 186-Lorenzo: "The Genesis Generation" Chapter 1
item.description: In today's podcast Lorenzo reads the first chapter of his new novel, "The Genesis Generation", which you may purchase at GenesisGeneration.us. This is a story about the transformation of a 29 year old "yuppie-geek" into an underground hero in the psychedelic community.

item.title: 185-McKenna: "Shamanism and the Archaic Revival"
item.description: Today's program features a talk by Terence McKenna that you can find elsewhere on the Net under the title "Vision Plants", but I thought that "Shamanism and the Archaic Revival" is more fitting. ... Among other provocative things McKenna has to say is, "Life lived in the absence of the psychedelic experience that primordial shamanism is based on is life trivialized, life denied, life enslaved to the ego."
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 184-Damer: "The Boundaries of the Human Mind"
item.description: Today's podcast features Bruce Damer, first at a Mind States conference in Oaxaca, Mexico and then in a late night conversation with Lorenzo. Among other things, Bruce talks about the team he led that developed some of the Virtual Reality simulations NASA used in training the astronaughts who recently repaired the Hubble telescope. ... However, the primary focus of Bruce's remarks may be summed up when he said, "If you want a future, you have to take charge of your own thoughts."

item.title: 183-Leary: "What Are Humans For"
item.description: This program features a 1983 interview with Dr. Timothy Leary which begins with him talking about the Sixties and some of the characters he was involved with back then. Among his more provocative comments are: "Harvard is there to train Ivy Leaguers to go to Washington and Wall Street and keep the wasp establishment going. They're not supposed to be turning out new Buddhas and a new brand of science fiction neuronaughts."

item.title: 182-Various: "The Spark of Divine Creativity"
item.description: Today we hear from two young traveling entertainers in a conversation with Mateo Pallamary and Lorenzo. Missy and Andre Nobels have been traveling around North America and entertaining with Missy's dancing and Andre's music. In this ad hoc conversation, the topic centers around creativity.

item.title: 181-McKenna: "What Science Forgot" Q&A
item.description: In today's podcast, we hear the Question and Answer session from the talk by Terence McKenna that we heard in my previous podcast. It begins with the question, "Can you talk about the relationship of advanced mathmatics to modeling of consciousness in layman's terms?". From there, Terence moves into thoughts about magic and his old favorite, language.

item.title: 180-McKenna: "Psychedelics: What Science Forgot"
item.description: In this wide-ranging talk, Terence McKenna ends on a high note saying: "We represent a kind of concrescence of universal intent. We're not mere spectators, or a cosmic accident, or some sideshow, or the Greek chorus to the main event. The human experience IS the main event."

item.title: 179-Leary: "Timothy Leary at Cornell - 1989"
item.description: This talk was given on April 23, 1989 by Dr. Timothy Leary at Cornell University. Among the other provocative things Dr. Leary has to say about religion (along many other topics) is: "No matter how crazy, fucked-up an individual can be, he can't be as fucked up as the Catholic Church."

item.title: 178-Leary+RAW "A random walk through two great minds"
item.description: In today's podcast I play three clips from the audio collection of the Timothy Leary archive. The first is a radio interview of Dr. Leary, and it is followed by an interview with Robert Anton Wilson for the same program a couple of days later. The last piece is the beginning of a talk that Timothy Leary gave at Cornell in 1984. In it, among the many other things Leary has to say is, "I have one cause, and that's the goal of the performing philosopher, is to encourage you, and inspire you, and empower you, to the extent I can, to Think for Yourself and Question Authority."
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 177-McKenna: "Surfing Finnegan's Wake" Part 2
item.description: This is the second half of McKenna's thoughts about James Joyce's novel, "Finnegan's Wake". But in a departure from where we left off in my previous podcast, Terence spins off on a tangent about Marshall McLuhan and ends with a rant about war and the evils of television. It's an interesting talk that could have been given yesterday for its relevance to our current state of affairs.

item.title: 176-McKenna: "Surfing Finnegan's Wake" Part 1
item.description: This is part 1 of a talk given by Terence McKenna in which he deconstructs James Joyce's monumental novel, "Finnegan's Wake". Among other interesting observations McKenna makes is, "The reason I'm interested in it is because it's two things, clearly. 'Finnegan's Wake' is psychedelic, and it is apolyptic/eschatlogical."

item.title: 175-Leary: "The Intelligent Use of Psychedelic Drugs"
item.description: Today we hear once again from Dr. Timothy Leary. This lecture was given in 1982 and covers a wide range of material, including an interesting overview of the use of psychedelics throughout history. Along with other provocative thoughts, he says, "We represent the aristocratic, exploring elite of our species, and we always have."

item.title: 174-McKenna: "Pushing the Envelope"
item.description: Today's program includes two Terence McKenna pieces. The first is of a Question and Answer session that one of our listeners discovered at the end of a video tape. As far as we know, these 25 minutes are new to the Net. The second talk is one that he gave at the Wetlands in New York on July 28, 1998. A wide range of topics are covered in these two talks, and the program notes with links to a transcript of the last talk may be found at: PsychedelicSalon (dot) org.

item.itunes:author: Lorenzo
item.itunes:summary: Today's program includes two Terence McKenna pieces. The first is of a Question and Answer session that one of our listeners discovered at the end of a video tape. As far as we know, these 25 minutes are new to the Net. The second talk is one that he gave at the Wetlands in New York on July 28, 1998. A wide range of topics are covered in these two talks, and the program notes with links to a transcript of the last talk may be found at: PsychedelicSalon (dot) org.

item.title: 173-Shulgin: "How I Go About Inventing New Drugs"
item.description: This week's program features a lecture by the master chemist, Sasha Shulgin. This talk was given at the Psychoactivity Conference in Amsterdam on 4 October 1998. In it, Sasha explains in detail how he goes about conceiving of and then creating completely new psychoactive compounds.

item.title: 172-Mind States: "The State of LSD in 2003"
item.description: In today's program we hear from Earth & Fire Erowid, Ralph Metzner, Stan Grof, Nick Sand, and David Nichols who were on a panel at the Mind States Conference in 2003 where they discussed the psychoactive compound, LSD. This is a follow up of podcast #154 in which the presentations by Nick Sand and Myron Stolaroff on this panel were previously presented.

item.title: 171-Leary: "The Technology of Freedom"
item.description: In this 1981 talk by Dr. Timothy Leary, he speaks about freedom, and about the technology we can use to achieve it. Among some of his other more provocative statements, he says: "Prison is a luxury. Unfortunately it is wasted on people who don't know how to use it."

item.title: 170-Trialogue: "How the Web Looked Back in 1994"
item.description: Today we hear what Ralph Abraham, Terence McKenna, and Rupert Sheldrake were thinking about the World Wide Web at a time before it was yet two years old. Recorded in Hawaii sometime in 1994, this was a private trialogue (conversation) between the three of them in the garden at Terence's house on the Big Island of Hawaii. Fortunately for us they had the foresight to turn on a tape recorder that day.

item.title: 169-Krishnamurti: "Truth is a Dangerous Thing"
item.description: This podcast is a collection of Krishnamurti sound bites taken from several of his videos currently available on YouTube. Among the many interesting ideas he presents, two could be of particular use to us at this moment in history, namely, his views about hope and faith.

item.title: 168-Trialogue: "What Hawaii Says About Evolution"
item.description: Today's podcast is from a cassette tape recording made by Ralph Abraham during a private trialogue between Terence McKenna, Rupert Sheldrake, and himself. It was recorded sometime in 1994 on the Big Island in Hawaii, most likely at Terence McKenna's home there. Their conversation about evolution includes an interesting comparision between the island of Hawaii and the island in space called planet Earth.

item.title: 167-Leary: "Evolution of Intelligence"
item.description: Today's talk is from a 1983 lecture given in Boulder, Colorado by Dr. Timothy Leary. Among the many other provocative things he has to say in this lecture is, "If you want to increase your intelligence, if you want to evolve, and grow, and go through the changes, the many changes that are possible, at all costs avoid terminal adulthood."

item.title: 166-McKenna: "Psychedelic Dreams"
item.description: This is a continuation of the talk by Terence McKenna in my previous podcast. It is from a lecture he (or someone?) once called "Dream Awake". Among Terence's many other words of wisdom in this talk is his famous statement: "The biggest danger with psychedelics is that while you are in that open state some moron will mess with you."

item.title: 165-Various Speakers: "Beats, Hippies, and McKenna"
item.description: Today's program is a mash-up of a conference Q&A session of a panel that included Timothy Leary, Allen Ginsberg, William S. Burroughs, Gregory Corso, and Abbie Hoffman. This short panel discussion is then followed by a talk by Terence McKenna where among other interesting things he says, "The global destiny of the [human] species is somehow unfolding with the logic of a dream."

item.title: 164-McKenna: "Some Thoughts About Ayahuasca"
item.description: In this talk, the bard Terence McKenna discusses some of his experiences in making and using the Vine. Among other things, he says, "[The ayahuasca experience] is is a self-generated, self-controlled immersion in a non-causal, parallel construct of some sort."

item.title: 163-Sententia: "Reality Syndromes & Cyberpunk Symptoms"
item.description: Today's talk comes from the 2003 Mind States Conference in Berkeley, California where Dr. Wrye Sententia speaks about some interesting aspects of consciousness and the reality it creates. Here is an example of one of Wrye's thought-provoking ideas" "And the reason I mention the decade of the drug wars [in connection with cyberpunk fiction] is because there are a lot of overlays between altering your mind through drugs and altering your mind through technologies, hard technologies."

item.title: 162-Forte: "Cultural Healing"
item.description: In this talk, given at the 4th annual Amazonian Shamanism Conference in Iquitos, Peru, Robert Forte challenges the psychedelic community to wake up and believe their own eyes about the events of 9-11. Only then, he believes, can we begin to move in the direction of healing our world cultures that are now in such deep conflict.

item.title: 161-Trialogue: "Reality Check"
item.description: Today's podcast is from a trialogue between Ralph Abraham, Rupert Sheldrake, and Terence McKenna sometime in 1992. In this extended conversation, they discuss the concept of utopias and where their work might fit in the history of utopian works. Among other items they discuss is the failed utopias of The Sixties.

item.title: 160-Leary: "The League for Spiritual Discovery"
item.description: In this January 1966 radio interview, Dr. Timothy Leary talks about his new religion, one whose sacrament is LSD. Among other provocative things he has to say is, "When the time comes, let your kids turn you on. That's my message to the middle-age, middle-class, whisky-drinking American suburban family."

item.title: 159-Forte-Shulgin: "Horizon's 2008-Perspectives on Psychedelics"
item.description: In this podcast, Lorenzo plays two selections from the talks given at the 2008 Horizon's Conference. The first is a talk given by Editor & Publisher Robert Forte, and the second is a question and answer session with Ann & Sasha Shulgin. More talks from this conference are available from The Internet Archive at www.archive.org/details/Horizons2008

item.title: 158-Wilson: "Increasing Human Life Span"
item.description: In this 1986 talk, author Robert Anton Wilson explores some of the issues surrounding human life expansion before moving on to discuss the future and how some conspiracy theories seem to have some substance to them.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 157-Wilson: "The Acceleration of Knowledge"
item.description: In this fascinating talk given sometime during the 1980s, Robert Anton Wilson paints a picture of an ever-increasing amount of information growing, and reverberating around the globe. And he draws some interesting conclusions about the importance of LSD and other psychedelic medicines.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 156-Fisher-Grob: "Treating Childhood Schizophrenia with Psychedelics"
item.description: In this program, Dr. Charles Grob (Professor of Psychiatry and Pediatrics at the UCLA School of Medicine and Director of the Division of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at Harbor-UCLA Medical Center) interviews Gary Fisher, Ph. D., about some experiments he conducted in the early 1960s. ... In addition to talking about the state of psychedelic research before prohibition closed down almost every study involving these non-patentable medicines, they discuss a previously unpublished paper Dr. Fisher wrote in which he detailed the results of his work giving LSD and psilocybin to severely emotionally disturbed children raging in age from 4 years 10 months to 12 years 11 months. ... The full report is available at www.MatrixMasters.com/GaryFisher
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 155-Leary: "Some Thoughts About Change (1945-1985)"
item.description: Today's podcast once again features Dr. Timothy Leary. The label on the cassette tape on which this talk was recorded gives the title of this lecture as "American Culture (1945-1985)", but in the talk Dr. Leary provides us with another title, "Some thoughts about change". No matter what you call this talk, the range of topics it covers means it is bound to touch on at least one of your interests. Program notes may be found at: www.PsychedelicSalon.org

item.title: 154-Sand-Stolaroff: "Mind States 2003 LSD Panel"
item.description: The legendary alchemist who created Orange Sunshine in the 60's, Nick Sand, and psychedelic pioneer, Myron Stolaroff, are featured in today's program. Nick talks about alchemy and LSD, and Myron speakes to the spiritual heights that may be reached through a careful balance of meditation and LSD.

item.title: 153-Wilson: "Consciousness Change and the 8-Circuit Model"
item.description: Today's podcast features an interview with the brilliant Robert Anton Wilson who offers a suggestion for an elightenment exercise that you can do at home among other interesting ideas. He also speaks openly about his use of psydhecelics and his view of their importance.

item.title: 152-Leary: "Question Authority and Think for Yourself"
item.description: In this 1987 talk, Dr. Timothy Leary, once called the High Priest of The Sixties, gives a Fort Worth, Texas audience a few ideas about how to challenge the status quo. Even though this talk was given over 20 years ago, it still holds up today.

item.title: 151-McKenna: "Posthumus Glory"
item.description: In today's podcast we hear selections from Terence McKenna's last two presentations at the AlChemical Arts Conference held on the big island of Hawaii in September 1999, just seven months before his untimely death. Among other little gems you will hear in these talks are how Terence was dealing with his final illness and a farewell thank you to the psychedelic community. Also included is part of a panel discussion that Terence and Tom Robbins held in which they discussed psychedelic literature.

item.title: 150-McKenna: "UFOs"
item.description: In a talk given at a convention of UFO enthusiasts, Terence McKenna tells the audience to save their time looking to the skys, because the aliens are already among us.

item.title: 149-Trilogue: "The Heavens"
item.description: In today's program, Rupert Sheldrake begins the conversation by examining the history of the sterilization of the cosmos into a mechanistic machine. Then he goes on to invite speculation by Terence McKenna and Ralph Abraham as to the possibility of stars having consciousness. All-in-all, this trialogue provides an interesting history of how humans have viewed the cosmos over the ages.

item.title: 148-Chopra: "Grand Rounds-Psychedelic Psychotherapy"
item.description: In today's podcast Dr. Preet Chopra talks about psychedelic psychotherapy in his grand rounds at a California hospital. Besides bringing us up to date on the psilocybin research project he is involved in, Dr. Chopra gives us some idea of the direction psychotherapy is taking in regards to psychedelic medicines.

item.title: 147-Wilson: "TSOG and Conspiracies"
item.description: Today's program features two interviews with Robert Anton Wilson. The first one features his book "Everything Is Under Control" and the second covers conspiracy theories and his book "TSOG: The Thing That Ate the Constitution".
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 146-McKenna: "The Importance of Human Beings"
item.description: In this lecture (originally titled "Eros to Eschaton") Terence McKenna says, "If in fact the conservation and complexification of novelty is what the universe is striving for, then suddenly our own human enterprise, previously marginalized, takes on an immense new importance." And from that foundation he goes on to claim that we humans "are the main event".

item.title: 145-Leary: "Live at the Inside Edge"
item.description: This is a talk given by Dr. Timothy Leary sometime late in 1991 or in 1992 at The Inside Edge in Orange County, California. Among the challenging ideas Dr. Leary presented was his thought that: "As soon as you belong to a system where you're not known individually, and where you don't know, individually, the other people, you are by definition depersonalizing yourself, a robot cog of the Big Machine."
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 144-Huxley: "The Ultimate Revolution"
item.description: In this 1962 talk, Aldous Huxley examines the possibility that events he wrote about in his novel, "Brave New World", are actually coming to pass. In this lecture, titled "The Ultimate Revolution" he also talks about terrorism, state terrorism.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)
item.itunes:subtitle: In this 1962 talk, Aldous Huxley examines the possibility that events he wrote about in his novel, "Brave New World", are actually coming to pass. In this lecture, titled "The Ultimate Revolution" he also talks about terrorism, state terrorism.

item.title: 143-Trialogue: "Rethinking Society"
item.description: In this 1992 trialogue, Terence McKenna sets the stage with Ralph Abraham and Rupert Sheldrake by talking about the power of images and the need for society to begin a serious discussion about how to make it more liveable. This talk has a lot of unexpected twists and turns along with a few laughs as well.

This talk has a lot of unexpected twists and turns along with a few laughs as well.

item.title: 142-Leary: "The Creation of the Future"
item.description: In this 1980 talk by Dr. Timothy Leary he recommends turning the reins of power to the young, and he makes a surprising suggestion about the proper age at which voting rights should be bestowed on our citizens.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 141-Trialogue: "Contemplating a Visual Psychedelic Language"
item.description: In this 1992 Trialogue, Ralph Abraham, Terence McKenna, and Rupert Sheldrake discuss the necessity of evolving language beyond words and text into a more condensed art form in order to better discuss psychedelic experiences.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)
item.itunes:subtitle: In this 1992 Trialogue, Ralph Abraham, Terence McKenna, and Rupert Sheldrake discuss the necessity of evolving language beyond words and text into a more condensed art form in order to better discuss psychedelic experiences.

item.title: 140-Grey: "Psychedelic Families" and Abraham "Psychedelics and Mathematical Vision"
item.description: In this podcast you will hear two presentations. The first is a talk given by Allyson and Alex Grey at the World Psychedelic Froum held in Basel, Switzerland in March of 2008 in which they discuss the difficult issue of educating our children about psychedelics. Next we hear the introduction to a 1992 trialogue in which Ralph Abraham describes the history of psychedelic involvement with the math and computer revolutions of the 1960s.

item.title: 139-Damer: "Is the Universe Waking Up"
item.description: In this podcast we hear Bruce Damer first at the Mind States conference in Oaxaca, Mexico in 2006 and then again in a more intimate setting in April 2008. His topics include views of the big picture of the universe possibly becoming aware of itself down to the world of today in which we may be frying our brains with too much time in front of our computers.

item.title: 138-Shulgin: "The Shulgins at Mind States 2005"
item.description: In this "Ask the Shulgins" session, in addition to some interesting chemistry questions, we learn more detail about the process Sasha uses to develop a new psychoactive substance. And Ann adds many soothing answers to some pressing questions.

item.title: 137-Leary: "Creation of the Future”
item.description: In this 1979 talk, Dr. Timothy Leary sets out a rather unique view of what today might be called "intelligent design", but with a Tim Leary twist, of course.

item.description: In today's podcast we hear Carolyn "Mountain Girl" Garcia's talk at the World Psydhecelid Formu in Basel, Switzerland during March of 2008. In it she recaps some of the highlights of her life as a Merry Prankster and as one of the cornerstones of The Greatful Dead.

item.title: 134-Pinchbeck: "A Playalogue about Sex and Social Control, Tantra and Liberation"
item.description: In today's podcast we join Daniel Pinchbeck for the playalogue he conducted at the 2007 Burning Man Festival. As part of the Palenque Norte lecture series, Daniel led a conversation about human sexual relations during a period of transformation between two ages. And later we hear Matt Pallamary's definition of shamanism.

item.title: 133-Leary: "The CyberSociety"
item.description: In this 1987 talk, Dr. Timothy Leary talks about the progression of technology that has brought humans to a new plateau of consciousness. And we also hear a personal, 1995 message from Eldridge Cleaver to Timothy Leary on a rather surprising subject.

item.title: 132-McKenna: "Shamanism" and Pallamary: "Spirit Matters"
item.description: In the first part of this podcast Terence McKenna gives us a few of his thoughts about shamanism. Also we hear from author Matt Pallamary, whose new memoir, "Spirit Matters" has just been published.

item.title: 131-Danforth: "Building a Model for Sustainable Psychedelic Therapy"
item.description: In today's program we hear the Playalogue led by Alicia Danforth at the 2007 Burning Man Festival. Along with input from the audience, Alicia covers many of the possibilities for continuing this important work.

item.title: 130-Leary: 1966 Radio Interview
item.description: In this podcast we feature a radio interview of Dr. Timothy Leary conducted by the infamous conservative talk show host, Alan Burke, who did his best to abuse and discredit Dr. Leary. It is truly a sign of the 1960s panic about the interest young people were showing in LSD.

item.title: 127-Leary: "How To Use Your Head"
item.description: This podcasat features Dr. Timothy Leary in his famous Cooper Union address when he told the American public about a chemical called LSD. Delivered in November 1964, this talk was one of the opening salvos of the cultural revolution of the Sixties.

item.title: 120-Lorenzo: "Notes to Myself"
item.description: Lorenzo muses on what it means to live a psychedelic life, and he is joined by several of his musician friends along with a brief sound bite from Terence McKenna.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 119-McKenna: "A Crisis of Consciousness"
item.description: In this talk by Terence McKenna, among other things, he says, "It is a crisis in consciousness which confronts us globally. Consciousness is the commodity that if we do not have enough of it, do not produce it fast enough, then the momentum of the processes we set in motion in our ignorance is going to sterilize the planet and do us all in."

item.title: 118-Ramachandran: "What Neurology Can Tell Us About Human Nature, Synesthesia and Art"
item.description: In this program neurologist Dr. V.S. Ramachandran talks about various ways in which brain structure can influence various forms of human behaviour, including the artistic impulse.

item.title: 117-McKenna: "The Importance of Psychedelics"
item.description: In this lecture, Terence McKenna talks about the tragic situation we humans have placed ourselves in, and ways in which the boundry dissolution effects of psychedelic medicines can possibly save our species from what appears to be a certain extinction. . . . "What the psychedelic experience does, really, is it stretches the envelope of the imaginable."

item.title: 115-Pesce: "Bios and Logos"
item.description: In this talk that was delivered at the 2002 Mind States Conference held in Jamaica, Mark Pesce discusses, among other things, the technological singularity, DNA, and nanotechnology and how they relate to the ongoing evolution of our species.

item.title: 114-McKenna: "Psychedelic Society"
item.description: In this talk given in 1984, Terence McKenna describes his vision of a society based on psychedelic thinking. This is the talk that eventually evolved into his famous essay with the same title.

item.title: 111-Leaf: "Establishing a Tribal Land Base"
item.description: This is a Palenque Norte playalogue that was moderated by Seabrook Leaf at the 2007 Burning Man festival. In this far-ranging conversation the concept of tribe is explored. Also, there are several stories about both successful and unsuccessful intentional communities.

item.title: 110-Trialogue: Hazelwwood House (Part 4)
item.description: In this final installment of the Hazelwood House trialogues, Ralph Abraham begins talking about "Fractals on my mind, an epic in four parts". He is then joined by Terence McKenna and Rupert Sheldrake in a discussion of ways in which mathematics impacts metaphysical thinking.

item.title: 109-Trialogue: Hazelwwood House (Part 3)

item.title: 108-Trialogue: Hazelwwood House (Part 2)

item.title: 107-Trialogue: Hazelwood House (Part1)
item.description: In their first trialogue held outside of California, Terence McKenna, Ralph Abraham, and Rupert Sheldrake begin this session by telling us what they think about one another. Then Rupert Sheldrake challenges Terence and Ralph to speculate on the as yet unknown physical principle underlying the ability of homing pigeons to return to their roosts. . . . This is part 1 of a four part trialogue.

item.title: 106-Damer: "The Ultimate Revelation: How Rare We Are in the Universe"
item.description: In this 2007 Burning Man Playalogue sponsored by Palenque Norte, futurist Bruce Damer leads a community discussion about how rare life appears to be in the universe. And he has a few suggestions about what we might want to do about it.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 105-Ameringo: "My Life as a Shaman and Artist"
item.description: The artist whose ayahuasca visions have inspired fans all over the world, Pablo Ameringo, is the guest lecturer in this podcast. Here he talks about his early life, and why he decided to take the path of the plants. Then he tells us what the plants have been saying to him lately. . . . At the end of the program, Lorenzo announces the schedule for the first ever Palenque Norte Playalogues, which will be held at the Burning Man Art Festival this year.

item.description: This is an interview Lorenzo did with Matt Pallamary about the topic of ayahuasca. Included in their conversation is a discussion of the recommended ayahuasca diet, ritual ways in which the medicine is used, and its potential for personal transformation.

item.title: 088-Chopra: "Report on Psilocybin Study"
item.description: At the 2006 Burning Man festival, Dr. Preet Chopra gave a Palenque Norte lecture in which he reported on the progress of a study being conducted at Harbor-UCLA Medical Center. This is a podcast of that lecture where you will hear how psychiatrists are treating people suffering from end-stage cancer and suffering from anxiety with an experimental protocol that includes using psilocybin, the active ingredient of magic mushrooms.

item.title: 087-Greer: "MDMA Before Ecstasy"
item.description: From 1980 to 1985, Dr. George Greer and his wife/Nurse-assistant, Requa Tolbert administered MDMA over 100 times to 80 people as part of his clinical psychiatric practice. According to the Heffter Research Institute, of which George is the Medial Director, George and Requa's review of their work remains the largest published study of the therapeutic use of MDMA. In this podcast we join George and Requa for their 2006 Palenque Norte lecture at Burning Man, where they discussed their earlier work.

item.title: 057-Pinchbeck: "Aliens, Elementals, and the Daimonic Realm"
item.description: Here is Daniel Pinchbeck speaking at the Oracle Gathering in Seattle at the end of October 2006 where he discussed "meeting the other". In this presentation he asks, are the entities met in aliens abductions, fairy stories, and psychedelic visions actual "others" or projected aspects of our own psyche? How can we understand and articulate these encounters in a meaningful way?
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 056-Lorenzo: "The Other Side of 2012"
item.description: This is a talk that Lorenzo gave at an Oracle Gathering in Seattle at the end of October 2006. In it he discusses three possible approaches to the 2012 meme: Muddling along, waiting for a mystical/magical transformation, or taking charge of your own life and planning for a personal change even though no major external events occur.

item.title: 055-Pendell: "Horizon Anarchism"
item.description: In his 2006 Palenque Norte lecture at Burning Man, Dale Pendell introduced the concept of Horizon Anarchism, and we are fortunate to be able to present this talk in its entirity in this edition of the Psychedelic Salon. If you think you know everyting there is to know about anarchism, you owe it to yourself to hear Dale's talk about this interesting new approach. One of my favorite soundbites is "Isolation is one of the keys of state power. So it is very important for us to get together and have fun."

item.title: 054-Sand: "Synergistic Combinations in the Future"
item.description: In his 2006 Palenque Norte lecture at Burning Man, Nick Sand explains how best to use some of the more interesting combinations of sacred medicines. Additionally he answered a wide range of questions that included such diverse topics as the relationship of the atomic bomb to LSD and the reasons he left the quiet life of academia to create Orange Sunshine, which was considered to be some of the best acid available in the 1960s.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 053-Shulgin: "Ask the Shulgins" (Burniong Man 2006)
item.description: This program features Ann and Sasha Shulgin in their 2006 appearance at Burning Man where they participated in the Palenque Norte lecture series with their ever-popular "Ask the Shulgins" question and answer session. . . . Also, Sasha describes how his first mescaline experience led to his future experiments with various compounds . . . and he warns about the unpredictability of these substances.

item.title: 052-Grey: "The Future of Visionary Art" (Part 2)
item.description: This is the second part of the Art Panel presentation for the Palenque Norte lectures at the 2006 Burning Man festival. This program consists of the remaining Q&A with the audience and Erik Davis' rap about the importance of visionary art.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 051-Grey: "The Future of Visionary Art" (Part 1)
item.description: This program is part one of the Art Panel presentation for the Palenque Norte lectures at the 2006 Burning Man festival. In this program Alex Grey talks about the purpose of visionary art, Allyson Grey explains her vision of personal sacred spaces, Martina Hoffmann advises us to not underestimate our own creativity, and Roberto Venosa describes the process of channeling energy from higher dimensions into visionary art.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 050-Pinchbeck: "Cancel the Apocalypse"
item.description: Daniel Pinchbeck brings us up to date with his current thinking about mythical cycles, the Mayan calendar, time as a quality, psychic evolution, and a wide range of other topics that he investigated while researching his new book, "2012: The Return of Quetzalcoatl". Among other things Daniel discusses in this, his 2006 Palenque Norte lecture at Burning Man, is "a massive upsurge in synchronicities" and "reality becoming more psychically malleable".
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 049-Davis: "Pharmacology and the Posthuman Phuture"
item.description: In his inspiring 2006 Palenque Norte lecture at Burning Man, Erik Davis takes a peek at what the future may have in store for us. And contrary to so much of the doom and gloom we hear all around us these days, Erik's message is that there is much hope for humanity in the future. This talk is certainly thought-provoking and is not to be missed.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

This talk is certainly thought-provoking and is not to be missed.

item.title: 048-Various: Palenque Norte 2006 Sampler
item.description: This was the most ambitious schedule yet for the Palenque Norte lectures, 39 speakers in four days. Thanks to the good folks at Entheon Village who provided the facility, which was one of the largest tents on the playa this year, they took place without too many problems sneaking up on us. In this podcast you will hear sound bites from the talks given by Mark Pesce, Erik Davis, Daniel Pinchbeck, Alex Grey, Allyson Grey, and Nick Sand. In the weeks ahead, their complete presentations will be podcast for those of you who weren't able to make it to the burn this year.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

In the weeks ahead, their complete presentations will be podcast for those of you who weren't able to make it to the burn this year.

item.title: 047-Damer: "The Day the Universe Becomes Conscious"
item.description: Terence McKenna once called Bruce Damer “a visionary's visionary,” and Bruce certainly lived up to that reputation in his 2003 Burning Man presentation. Combining subjects as diverse as evolution, psychedelic experiences, and physics, he builds a mental construct to rival Olaf Stapleton's classic work "Starmaker". In addition to Bruce's ideas about a conscious universe, we were also treated to an interesting rap by his wife, Galen Brandt, as she explaines the lure of the Burning Man experience.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 046-Aisner "Reproducible Experiences on Different Entheogens"
item.description: RafaelO Aisner explains how to create reproducible experiences with MDMA, psilocybin, LSD, DMT, 5-MEO-DMT, 2CI, 2CB, 2CT7, 2CT2, and mescaline. This talk was originally given at the 2004 Palenque Norte lectures at Burning Man.

item.title: 045-Clark "Rave Culture And the End Of The World . . . . . . as we know it"
item.description: Fraser Clark returns to the Psychedelic Salon with a brilliant talk he gave as a guest lecturer at Stanford University. In his introduction to this podcast, Lorenzo calls this one of the most important programs we have heard so far in this series. In this talk you're going to hear one off the most concise explanations of the evolution from beat to hippy to zippy to raver that you're probably ever going to hear.Adopting the philosophy of the rave culture, at least the way Fraser explains it in this talk, is perhaps our species' best hope for a sustainable, peaceful, and beautiful place to continue chugging along on our evolutionary path.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 044-Vanosky-Candelaria: “A Conversation About How Communities Come About”
item.description: Ken Vanosky and Jerry Candelaria moderated the most interactive of the 2003 Palenque Norte conversations at Burning Man, and in this recording you will also hear from several members of the audience who added some significant thoughts of their own.

item.title: 038-Zoe7: “Mind Machines, Entheogens, and the Expansion of Consciousness”
item.description: Zoe7 is a multi-dimensional synergy personality cluster who inhabits the body and mind of consciousness researcher, Joseph Marti. (The other five personalities are: Max McCullan, Ebhrious, Jiebro, Kzark Prestidius, and Lee Steel.) His book, "Into The Void Exploring Consciousness, Hyperspace and Beyond Using Brain Technology, Psychedelics and Altered-Mind States", depicts Marti’s experiments with mind machines, entheogens, and psychological time travel, how the Zoe7 cluster came to be, as well as new theories on parallel universes and probable Earths, the mechanics of reality and existence, and the mind of God.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 037-Sand: "Reflections on Imprisonment and Liberation as Aspects of Consciousness"
item.description: Nick Sand, one of the original psychedelic guides from the Millbrook commune, alchemist, yogi, spiritual practitioner, and drug war victim, discusses the psychological states encountered as an underground chemist, a fugitive, and his five years in prison. The topics dealt with will be how attitude, intention, and time, reveal the reality of true inner freedom.
item.author: hagerty@matrixmasters.com (Lorenzo)

item.title: 036-McKenna: "In the Valley of Novelty" (Part 10)
item.description: In this last of a ten part series, Terence McKenna closes this workshop with some thoughts about psychedelics as time machines, the forest of the Internet, the erotization of our technology, a form of circus called the DMT experience, and ending with some pracitical tools you can use to prepare for a psychydelic experience.

item.title: 035-McKenna "In the Valley of Novelty" (Part 9)
item.description: In just 50 minutes, Terence McKenna talks about how great cultures can lose their way, transforming machine-elves, the story of psychedelic psychotherapy, the Balkanization of epistemology, the UFO community as a social phenomenon, the role of psychedelics in the world corporate state, nanotechnology, time machines and the singularity. . . . See if you can keep up with this Niagara of ideas.

item.title: 034-McKenna: "In the Valley of Novelty" (Part 8)
item.description: Terence McKenna talks about: The evolution of art representing the human form, The impact of psilocybin on human sexuality, How to build a gravity bong, More thoughts on "the AI" being an obvious consequence of the Internet, Further discussion about the Timewave Theory, How his thoughts about the eschaton affect his daily life, Psychedelics and the end of your spiritual childhood.
